Title: Fly: Studying the Perception of Canvas Presentations
Author list: Leonhard Lichtschlag, Thorsten Karrer, Thomas Hess
Keywords: Creativity Support Tools; Visualization; E-Learning and Education; User Studies
Abstract: Most presentation software uses the slide deck metaphor to create visual presentation support. Recently, canvas presentation tools such as Fly or Prezi have begun to use a zoomable free-form canvas to arrange information instead. While their effect on authoring presentations has been evaluated previously, we studied how they impact the audience. In a quantitative study, we compared audience retention and macrostructure understanding of slide deck vs. canvas presentations. We found both approaches to be equally capable of communicating information to the audience. Canvas presentations, however, were rated by participants to better aid them in staying oriented during a talk. This makes canvas presentation tools a promising slideware alternative.

Title: Urban HCI: Spatial Aspects in the Design of Shared Encounters for Media Façades
Author list: Patrick Tobias Fischer, Eva Hornecker
Keywords: Interaction Design; Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Context-Aware Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Ethnography; Design Planning; Product Design; User Experience Design / Experience Design; Tangible UIs
Abstract: Designing interactive applications for Media Façades is a \ challenging task. Architectural sized large-scale screens can \ result in unbalanced installations, and meaningful interaction \ is easily overshadowed by the drastic size of the display. \ In this paper we reflect on urban technology \ interventions by analyzing their spatial configuration in relation \ to the structuring of interaction. We outline basic \ categories and offer a new terminology to describe these interactive \ situations designed for the built environment.

Title: DiskPlay: In-Track Navigation on Turntables
Author list: Florian Heller, Jan Borchers
Keywords: Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Tangible UIs; Creativity Support Tools
Abstract: Although digital media playback and storage has several advantages, the direct manipulation of the record and the haptics of the turntable makes vinyl the preferred tool for many DJs. The physical structure of traditional vinyl provides several cues for in-track navigation such as track length or the mood of the song. Digital vinyl systems use a timecode record to combine the advantages of digital playback with the handling DJs are used to. The record contains a special audio signal that is processed by a computer and mapped to information such as playback speed, direction, and absolute position. However, the visualization is separated from the control and due to their generic nature, timecode records do not provide visual information for in-track navigation. DiskPlay augments a timecode record with visual cues known from traditional vinyl or common DJ practice. In an observational study with four professional DJs the system was received very well and showed to reduce the number of focus switches.

Title: Vignette: Interactive Texture Design and Manipulation with Freeform Gestures for Pen-and-Ink Illustration
Author list: Rubaiat Habib Kazi, Takeo Igarashi, Shengdong Zhao, Richard Davis
Keywords: Entertainment; Pen and Tactile Input; Interaction Design; Prototyping; Process Improvement; User Interface Design; Pen-based UIs; Creativity Support Tools
Abstract: We present Vignette, an interactive system for pen-and-ink illustration that preserves illustrators’ workflow and style. Vignette provides a novel painting workflow, where the user draws a fraction of a texture and the system automatically extends it along the guiding strokes or fills a region with the texture. It facilitates the creation of a wide range of textures with built in texture synthesis capabilities, including 1D and 2D synthesis with stitching. Our system also has, interactive refinement and editing capabilities to provide a higher level texture control, which helps artists achieve their desired vision. Our user study with professional artists shows that Vignette makes the process of illustration more enjoyable and that first time users can create rich textures from scratch within minutes.

Title: StoryCrate: Tabletop Storyboarding for Live Film Production
Author list: Tom Bartindale, Alia Sheikh, Nick Taylor, Peter Wright, Patrick Olivier
Keywords: Creativity Support Tools; Video Content / Communications; Entertainment; Prototyping
Abstract: Since its conception in 1926 television has become a part of our everyday life, but how much do we know about how it is made? Broadcast content is consumed at an astounding rate through many different mediums, and yet the pressure is on to produce quality product cheaper and faster. Technology advances have been made in capture and editing, but these technologies are often disparate and discrete within the workflow. Can we facilitate creativity among crew members, making use of new interaction technologies? We present a tangible interface for on-location film shoots which facilitates creative media production among the crew, and discuss a number of interesting interactions that were elicited from an initial study with the device.

Title: Enabling Self, Intimacy and a Sense of Home in Dementia: An Enquiry into Design in a Hospital Setting
Author list: Jayne Wallace, Anja Thieme, Gavin Wood, Guy Schofield, Patrick Olivier
Keywords: Emotion and Affective User Interface; Elderly; Health Care; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards)
Abstract: Design and digital technologies to support a sense of self and human relationships for people living with dementia are both urgently needed. We present an enquiry into design for dementia facilitated by a public art commission for an adult mental health unit in a hospital in the UK. The interactive art piece was informed by the notion of personhood in dementia that foregrounds the person's social being and interpersonal relationships as sites where self is maintained and constructed. How clients, clients' family members and staff used the piece is reported and insights related to the notions of home, intimacy, possessions and self are presented. The art piece served as window on both dementia and the institution leading to a number of insights and implications for design.

Title: Becoming-Sound: Affect and Assemblage in Improvisational Digital Music-Making
Author list: Benjamin Swift
Keywords: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
Abstract: The concepts of affect and assemblage proposed by critical \   thinkers such as Gilles Deleuze and Brian Massumi have had little \   impact in mainstream HCI theory.  However, these concepts can be of \   assistance in understanding the interactions that take place between \   users and artefacts in interactive systems, particularly in the \   context of computer-supported creativity.  In this paper we provide an introduction \   to affect and assemblage theory for HCI practitioners.  We then use \   a case study of Viscotheque, an iOS-based interface for group \   musical collaboration, to demonstrate the application of affective \   analysis in making sense of complex interaction. \

Title: What Else Should We Expect  From Research Through Design?
Author list: William Gaver
Keywords: Interaction Design; Industrial Design; Concept Design; Product Design; User Experience Design / Experience Design
Abstract: In this essay, I explore several facets of research through design in order to contribute to discussions about how the approach should develop. The essay has three parts. In the first, I review a range of theoretical work that has emerged from research through design, and use two influential theories from the Philosophy of Design to help reflect on the nature of design theory. In the second part, I discuss three possible interpretations for the diversity of approaches to research through design, and suggest that this variation need not be seen as a sign of inadequate standards or a lack of cumulative progress in the field. In the final section, I suggest that, rather than aiming to develop increasingly comprehensive theories of design, practice based research might better view theory as annotation of realised design examples, and particularly portfolios of related pieces. Overall, I suggest that the design research community should embrace its theories as provisional, inspirational and annotative, its diversity as a positive implication of its field of investigation, and its tendency to produce an endless string of artefacts as its highest goal.

Title: ClayVision: The (Elastic) Image of the City
Author list: Yuichiro Takeuchi, Ken Perlin
Keywords: Augmented Reality; Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing
Abstract: In this paper we describe ClayVision, a new quasi-immersive urban navigation system that rethinks the design conventions of existing Augmented Reality (AR) applications, by aggressively incorporating knowledge from non-Computer Science fields-namely Information Design and Urban Planning. Instead of the prevailing approach of pasting "information bubbles" onto the existing urban scenery, ClayVision communicates through real-time 3D transformations of city elements. In other words, the system dynamically probes and reassembles the city into a better-designed copy of the original, that is both easier to navigate and tailored to suit the user's needs and preferences. We provide extensive discussions that cover the technical details of the system, the types of city-morphing operations that can be effectively applied, and what people's experiences will be in the newly "elastic" city.

Title: PINOKY: A Ring That Animates Your Plush Toys
Author list: Yuta Sugiura, Calista Lee, Masayasu Ogata, Yasutoshi Makino, Daisuke Sakamoto, Masahiko Inami, Takeo Igarashi
Keywords: Tangible UIs; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Interaction Design; Robots
Abstract: PINOKY is a wireless ring-like device that can be externally attached to any plush toy as an accessory that animates the toy, such as by moving its limbs. A user is thus able to instantly convert any plush toy into a soft robot. The user can control the toy remotely or input the movement desired by moving the plush toy and having the data recorded and played back. Unlike other methods for animating plush toys, PINOKY is non-intrusive, so alterations to the toy are not required. In a user study, 1) the roles of plush toys in the participants’ daily lives were examined, 2) how the participants played with plush toys without PINOKY was observed, 3) how they played with plush toys with the device was observed and their reactions to the device were surveyed. On the basis of the results, potential applications were conceptualized to illustrate the utility of PINOKY.

Title: Interpreting Input from Children: a Designerly Approach
Author list: Christopher Frauenberger, Judith Good, Wendy Keay-Bright, Helen Pain
Keywords: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Children; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design
Abstract: Involving children in the design process of interactive technology can greatly enhance its likelihood of successful adoption, particularly when designers, researchers and teachers are able to interpret ideas from a child's perspective of the world. However, this interpretation of children’s ideas into viable designs and technical specifications presents the biggest challenge for the adult design research team. In this paper we discuss our approach to managing the complexity of combining concepts and ideas that were generated through participatory design work with the practical, technical, ethical and theoretical constraints of developing a technologically enhanced learning environment for children. In particular, we will describe a workshop in which members of the design team aimed to make sense of the outcomes of the participatory activities and to translate them into a design brief. This brief needed to inspire and inform a large multidisciplinary team from outside of the visual design discipline: psychology, computer science and education. During the intense two days of the workshop we used design methods to shape the under-defined and "wicked" problem space with which we were faced. With this paper we aim to further the case for using such designerly approaches in combination with participatory and human-centred methods to develop interactive technology. We found that the nature of our design problem did not lend itself to be rationally reduced to produce a single solution, but that it required an understanding of interpretive and speculative approaches for us to be able to cope with the complexity of requirements.

Title: KidCAD: Digitally Remixing Toys Through Tangible Tools
Author list: Sean Follmer, Hiroshi Ishii
Keywords: Creativity Support Tools; Children; Tactile & Haptic UIs; Tangible UIs
Abstract: Children have great facility in the physical world, and can skillfully model in clay and draw expressive illustrations. Traditional digital modeling tools have focused on mouse, keyboard and stylus input. These tools may be complicated and difficult for young users to easily and quickly create exciting designs. We seek to bring physical interaction to digital modeling, to allow users to use existing physical objects as tangible building blocks for new designs. We introduce KidCAD a digital clay interface for children to remix toys. KidCAD allows children to imprint 2.5D shapes from physical objects into their digital models by deforming a malleable gel input device, deForm. Users can mashup existing objects, edit and sculpt or draw new designs on a 2.5D canvas using physical objects, hands and tools as well as 2D touch gestures. We report on a preliminary user study with 13 children, ages 7 to 10, which provides feedback for our design and helps guide future work in tangible modeling for children.

Title: Developing IDEAS: Supporting children with autism within a participatory design team
Author list: Laura Benton, Hilary Johnson, Emma Ashwin, Mark Brosnan, Beate Grawemeyer
Keywords: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Children; User Interface Design
Abstract: IDEAS (Interface Design Experience for the Autistic Spectrum) is a method for involving children with Autistic Spectrum Disorders (ASD) in the technology design process. This paper presents a new version of the method, for use with a design team and providing specific additional support for communication and collaboration difficulties that may arise. A study to trial the new IDEAS method was conducted with two design teams, each involving three children with ASD, in a series of six, weekly design sessions focused on designing a maths game. The findings from this study reveal that the children were able to successfully participate in the sessions and collaborate with other children. The findings also highlight the positive experience that involvement in such a process can offer this population.

Title: How Students Find, Evaluate and Utilize Peer-Collected Annotated Multimedia Data in Science Inquiry with Zydeco
Author list: Alex Kuhn, Brenna McNally, Shannon Schmoll, Clara Cahill, Wan-Tzu Lo, Chris Quintana, Ibrahim Delen
Keywords: E-Learning and Education; Children; User Studies
Abstract: Science inquiry can be more authentic and meaningful when using personal and peer collected multimedia data. The challenges of organizing and evaluating this large amount of data can be overcome through the use of annotations (title, tags, and audio notes) on photographic data. We created Zydeco, a multi-part system that had students collect annotated multimedia data from a museum using a mobile component, then utilize a tablet app to put together an explanation with their personal and peers’ data. We ran a study in a classroom with 54 students (aged 11-13) investigating how students searched for, evaluated, and choose to utilize annotated data for constructing a science explanation. We found that tags were able to support interpreting data, while students used browsing and title searching primarily to find and utilize data.

Title: MOSOCO: A Mobile Assistive Tool to Support Children with Autism Practicing Social Skills in Real-Life Situations
Author list: Lizbeth Escobedo, David H. Nguyen, Gillian Hayes, LouAnne Boyd, Alejandro Rangel, J. Daniel Garcia, Sen Hirano, Monica Tentori
Keywords: Children; Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Health Care; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Interaction Design; Prototyping; User Studies; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Augmented Reality
Abstract: MOSOCO is a mobile assistive application that uses augmented reality and the visual supports of a validated curriculum, the Social Compass, to help children with autism practice social skills in real-life situations. In this paper, we present the results of a seven-week deployment study of MOSOCO in a public school in Southern California with students with autism and neurotypical students. The results of our study demonstrate that MOSOCO facilitates practicing and learning social skills, increases both quantity and quality of social interactions, reduces social and behavioral missteps, and enables the integration of children with autism in social groups of neurotypical children. The findings from this study reveal emergent practices of the uses of mobile assistive technologies in real-life situations.

Title: Representing “too small to see” as “too small to see”: Using Temporal Representation to Represent Imperceptible Spatial information
Author list: Minyoung Song, Chris Quintana
Keywords: Multi-modal interfaces; Children; E-Learning and Education; Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); Interaction Design; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; Multimedia UIs
Abstract: Teaching and learning the sizes of the objects that are too small to see with human eyes (called imperceptible sizes) has been a challenging issue in education. Because representation is the only medium that learners can make sense of imperceptible phenomena with, learners encounter challenges when trying to perceiving and conceptualizing imperceptible sizes. Existing studies imply that conventional visual representations that are incorporated in many learning technologies tend to direct learners to overestimate imperceptible sizes, hence, a need for a novel representation that can alter the way learners perceive and conceptualize imperceptible size emerges. To address this issue, we designed a multimodal representation (temporal-aural-visual representation: TAVR), which uses temporal sense as a main modality for representing imperceptible smallness. In a prior study [27] we found that the time is a useful concept that can be used to support learners to perceive and conceptualize imperceptible spatial information and TAVR is effective for refining learners’ mental model of imperceptible sizes. In this paper, we introduce a follow-up research that explored how to best augment the temporal experience of imperceptible size.

Title: Game Design for Promoting Counterfactual Thinking
Author list: Elizabeth Bonsignore, Allison Druin
Keywords: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Virtual Community / Community Computing; E-Learning and Education; User and Cognitive models; Design Planning; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; Visual System Design / Visual Design
Abstract: We describe the first iteration of an Alternate Reality Game (ARG) designed to lead players into a newly enfranchised relationship with history, engage them in scientific thinking and information literacy practices, and help them discover hidden stories that exist outside most history books. We found that the points at which the game’s mythology blurred the lines between fact and fiction prompted middle school students to move beyond rote memorization of content. Instead, they began to question, analyze, and make hypotheses about the data presented. However, striking a meaningful balance between “true” history and imagined events posed new design challenges. In this paper we present a formative typology of counterfactual design patterns that can help designers, educators, and players locate interesting fault lines in reality that facilitate the expansion of ARG mythologies. We include visual design strategies to help middle school players distinguish between fact and fiction, while still remaining “in-game.”

Title: Looking Glass: A Field Study on Noticing Interactivity of Shop Windows
Author list: Jörg Müller, Robert Walter, Gilles Bailly, Michael Nischt, Florian Alt
Keywords: Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Interaction Design; Branding; User Experience Design / Experience Design
Abstract: In this paper we present our findings from a lab and a field \ study investigating how passers-by notice the interactivity \ of public displays. We designed an interactive installation \ that uses visual feedback to the incidental movements of \ passers-by to communicate interactivity. The lab study reveals: \ (1) Mirrored user silhouettes and images are more \ effective than avatar-like representations. (2) It takes time \ to notice the interactivity (approx. 1.2s). In the field study, \ three displays were installed during three weeks in shop windows, \ and data about 807 persons interacting were collected. \ Our observations show: (1) Significantly more passers-by \ interact when immediately showing the mirrored user image \ (90% more) or silhouette (47%) compared to a traditional \ attract sequence with call-to-action. (2) Passers-by often notice \ interactivity late and have to walk back to interact (the \ landing effect). (3) If somebody is already interacting, others \ begin interaction behind the ones already interacting, forming \ multiple rows. Our findings can be used to design public \ display applications and shop windows that more effectively \ communicate interactivity to passers-by.

Title: Design of an Exergaming Station for Children with Cerebral Palsy
Author list: Hamilton Hernandez, Nicholas Graham
Keywords: Children; Entertainment; Health Care; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: We report on the design of a novel station supporting the play of exercise video games (exergames) by children with cerebral palsy (CP). The station combines a physical platform allowing children with CP to provide pedaling input into a game, a standard Xbox 360 controller, and algorithms for interpreting the cycling input to improve smoothness and accuracy of gameplay. The station was designed through an iterative and incremental participatory design process involving medical professionals, game designers, computer scientists, kinesiologists, physical therapists, and eight children with CP. It has been tested through observation of its use, through gathering opinions from the children, and through small experimental studies. With our initial design, only three of eight children were capable of playing a cycling-based game; with the final design, seven of eight could cycle effectively, and six of eight reached energy expenditure levels recommended by the American College of Sports Medicine.

Title: Chained Displays: Configurations of Public Displays can be used to influence Actor-, Audience-, and Passer-By Behavior
Author list: Maurice ten Koppel, Gilles Bailly, Jörg Müller, Robert Walter
Keywords: Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Interaction Design
Abstract: Most interactive public displays rely on flat screens that can negatively impact how users (1) notice the public display (2) develop motivation and (3) (socially) interact with the public display. In this paper, we present  Chained displays, a combination of several screens to create different form factors for interactive public displays. We also present a design space based on two complementary properties, Perceptibility and Observability, to describe and compare chained displays configurations. Finally, we performed a field study comparing three chained displays: Flat, Concave, and Hexagonal. Results show that Flat triggers the strongest honeypot effect, Hexagonal causes low social learning, and Concave triggers the smallest amount of simultaneously interacting users among other findings.

Title: Athletes and Street Acrobats: Designing for play as a Community Value
Author list: Annika Waern, Elena Balan, Kim Nevelsteen
Keywords: Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Entertainment; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; User Interface Design
Abstract: Participatory design methods face a challenge when designing for a widespread youth culture. In such projects, it is not enough to design in collaboration with a few selected individuals; one must also strive to understand the culture at a deeper level and incorporate its values and practices into the design solution. \  \ We report on our process of designing with, and for, an identified youth culture: the Parkour and Freerunning community. We show how the successful design relied not only on employing methods of participatory observation and participatory design, but also on acquiring an in-depth understanding of the practice informed by cultural and sociological studies. \

Title: Tales from the Front Lines of a Large-Scale Serious Game Project
Author list: Rilla Khaled, Gordon Ingram
Keywords: Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); E-Learning and Education; Entertainment; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design
Abstract: Serious games have received much positive attention; correspondingly, many researchers have taken up the challenge of establishing how to best design them. However, the current literature often focuses on best practice design strategies and frameworks, abstracting away more fine-grained details and contextual descriptions that are invaluable in helping us to understand, learn from, and reflect on our experiences. In this paper, we present five distinct and sometimes competing perspectives that are critical in understanding factors that influence serious game projects: project organisation, technology, domain knowledge, user research, and game design. We explain these perspectives by providing insights from the design and development process of an EU-funded serious game about conflict resolution developed by an interdisciplinary consortium of researchers and industry-based developers. We also point out a set of underlying forces that become evident from viewing the process from different perspectives, to underscore that problems exist in serious game projects and that we should open the conversation about them.

Title: Of BATs and APEs: Designing an Interactive Tabletop Game for Natural History Museums
Author list: Michael Horn, Zeina Atrash Leong, Florian Block, Judy Diamond, Margaret Evans, Brenda Caldwell Phillips, Chia Shen
Keywords: E-Learning and Education; Input and Interaction Technologies; Children; Interaction Design
Abstract: In this paper we describe the design and evaluation of Build-a-Tree (BAT), an interactive tabletop exhibit to help visitors learn about evolution in natural history museums. To test our design we video recorded 30 families using the exhibit at a well-known university natural history museum. We observed an additional 49 social groups interacting with the exhibit without video recording. One goal of this research is to explore ways to develop “successful” interactive elements for natural history museums using tabletop technology. To determine criteria for success in this context, we borrow the concept of Active Prolonged Engagement (APE) from the science museum literature, which sets a high standard for visitor engagement and learning. Our results show that visitor groups collaborated effectively and engaged in focused, on-topic discussion for prolonged periods of time. One possible explanation for these results is that our exhibit is a puzzle-based game. To explore this idea further, we analyzed conversation at the exhibit in depth to understand how visitors applied existing social practices of game play in the museum context. We also offer insights on the role of computer-based games in the natural history museums.

Title: Playable Character: Extending Digital Games into the Real World
Author list: Jason Linder, Wendy Ju
Keywords: Interaction Design; Prototyping; Sustainability
Abstract: This paper describes a series of research probe games developed to investigate how real-world activity could be incorporated into digital game systems. These culminated in the design of our final game, Forest, which was conceived for the San Francisco non-profit Friends of the Urban Forest (FUF), who have been planting and caring for the city's street trees for 30 years. By incorporating real-world actions and behaviors into digital games, we can create experiences that both enhance our understanding of the world around us and provide incentive structures towards our personal, community, or societal goals.

Title: The Impact of Tutorials on Games of Varying Complexity
Author list: Erik Andersen, Eleanor O'Rourke, Yun-En Liu, Rich Snider, Jeff Lowdermilk, David Truong, Seth Cooper, Zoran Popović
Keywords: Entertainment; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User Studies
Abstract: Teaching new users the functionality of an application, whether a video game or a software product, is one of the greatest challenges of interface design. Video game developers frequently depend on tutorials to communicate information to new players, yet there is little published work that evaluates the impact of tutorials on game learnability. To examine this question in more depth, we implemented eight tutorial designs proposed in HCI literature in three video games, and evaluated their effects on player engagement and retention. We present results from a multivariate study of over 45,000 players showing that game complexity influences the effectiveness of tutorial designs. We found that tutorials had a surprisingly negligible effect on player engagement in casual online games. The presence of context-sensitive tutorials and on-demand help were useful in the more complex game we studied, but in the simpler casual games they generally had no effect, or in the case of on-demand help, a negative effect. Additionally, the interactive tutorials that teach specific concepts by restricting player freedom had no significant effects on player engagement in any of the three games. These results suggest that tutorials have unpredictable effects on players, may depend on the complexity of the game in question, and that developers should be aware of the risks of seemingly straightforward tutorial design strategies.

Title: From Participatory to Contributory Simulations: Changing the Game in the Classroom
Author list: Stefan Kreitmayer, Yvonne Rogers, Robin Laney, Stephen Peake
Keywords: Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW)
Abstract: There is much potential for collaborative learning with interactive computer simulations in formal education and professional training. However, there is a lack of understanding of how such activities can be designed to fit into the large-group, co-located learning ecologies (such as classrooms) in which much of today's teaching takes place. Participatory Simulations have used ubiquitous technologies as a way to engage a whole room full of students in shared role-play-like interaction with computational models. This paper proposes Contributory Simulations as an instructional model which extends Participatory Simulations by empowering students to make informed, critical changes to the modeling, the interaction design and task definitions. Based on findings from our design and in-the-wild deployment of the [anon.] game on global climate economics we argue that Contributory Simulations enable a different kind of classroom-based teaching that is better suited to complex, controversial topics

Title: Introducing the Ambivalent Socialiser
Author list: Bernd Ploderer, Wally Smith, Steve Howard, Jon Pearce, Ron Borland
Keywords: Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Health Care; Prototyping
Abstract: Social interaction can be a powerful strategy for persuasive technology interventions, yet many users are reluctant to engage with others online because they fear pressure, failure, and shame. We introduce the ‘ambivalent socialiser’, people who are simultaneously keen but also reluctant to engage with others via social media. Our contribution is to identify four approaches to introducing sociality to ambivalent socialisers: structured socialising, incidental socialising, eavesdropping, and trace sensing. We discuss the rationale for these approaches and show how they address recent critiques of persuasive technology. Furthermore, we provide actionable insight for designers of persuasive technology by showing how these approaches can be implemented in a social media application.

Title: Empathy, Participatory Design and People with Dementia
Author list: Stephen Lindsay, Katie Britain, Patrick Olivier
Keywords: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Emotion and Affective User Interface; Elderly; User Experience Design / Experience Design
Abstract: We describe the development, application and evaluation of a design method tailored for working with people with mild to moderate dementia. Our experiences with the approach highlighted areas where designers and participants held radically different views. To overcome these differences, the tenet guiding this approach was to create an empathic relationship between participants and designers. To achieve this we modified participatory design techniques to foster respectful engagement with participants in the development of a digital aid to facilitate ‘safe walking’. The process begins with broad qualitative scoping work then, through iterative analysis, moves to developing personally tailored, individual designs to further exploration of the experiential elements of the domain while reducing the need for the participants to engage ion abstract thought. Reflections upon this process highlight a number of important areas that need consideration when undertaking research in this area and, more generally, when performing design work with people with dementia.

Title: Engaging Older People through Participatory Design
Author list: Stephen Lindsay, Patrick Olivier
Keywords: Elderly; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design
Abstract: The use of digital technologies is increasingly proposed in health and social care to address the aging population phenomenon but, in practice, the designers of these technologies are ill equipped to design for older people. We suggest participatory design as an approach to improving the quality of design for older people but, based on previous work and our own experiences, identify four central issues that participatory design approaches need to address. We describe an approach to early engagement in design with older people that address each of these issues and some of our experiences applying the approach in a variety of different design projects. We conclude by discussing some of the issues that have been highlighted when attempting apply this approach in different design contexts and the issues that have been raised when working with partners who are less committed to the idea of engaging with older adults in participatory design.

Title: Twiage: A Game for Finding Good Advice on Twitter
Author list: Max Van Kleek, Daniel Smith, Ruben Stranders, m.c. schraefel
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Information Architecture; Virtual Community / Community Computing; World Wide Web and Hypermedia
Abstract: Recommendations, opinions and personal experiences are being shared by millions of people on microblog networks each day. This paper looks at the feasibility and challenges for harvesting the “best of” such content, so that it may be more easily found and potentially re-purposed by individuals with advice-oriented information needs. We present our experiments with "Twiage", a game-with-a-purpose designed to let people quickly sift through a large volume of microblog entries to identify “good advice”.  The results of running this game demonstrate high agreement rates among people on what of those selections represents “good” advice, It also demonstrates the effectiveness of using the Elo rating algorithm to derive such rankings, and shows the efficiency achieved for various levels of desired agreement.  We show that by further validating the quality of selected entries using expert evaluation, we uncovered the need to more aggressively eliminate “weak spam” that non-domain expert crowds did not discern: promotional material and advertisements disguised as articles and reviews.

Title: V-Model : A New Innovative Model for Chronologically Visualizing Narrative Clinical Texts
Author list: Heekyong Park, Jinwook Choi
Keywords: Health Care; Context-Aware Computing; Visualization; Office and Workplace; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); User and Cognitive models; Visual Design; Visual System Design / Visual Design; User Interface Design
Abstract: Visualizing narrative medical events into timeline would have positive effects on clinical environments. However, natural language characteristics and medical environments make the representation more difficult. This paper explains the obstacles and suggests a solution, V-Model. V-Model is a new innovative time model that is developed for representing chronological narrative events in medical domain. Forty medical students participated in evaluating this model. The experimental results show that the new model successfully solves the modeling requirements and has better usability compared to conventional timeline models. All the participants assessed the new timeline is very useful for understanding a patient’s history effectively.

Title: Tackling Dilemmas in Supporting “The Whole Person” in Online Patient Communities
Author list: Jina Huh, Rupa Patel, Wanda Pratt
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Health Care
Abstract: Patient-centered medicine advocates addressing the ‘whole person’ and viewing patients’ medical concerns within the context of the world in which they live. Online patient communities have emerged as important areas where patients can get experiential knowledge. However, how much these communities support the whole patient—both medical and personal side—is an open question. To gain insights into these questions, we examined a sample of online patient communities to understand health professionals’ involvement in bringing in medical advice into peer-patient experience sharing and various ways in which illness experiences are shared among patients. We found the communities fall short in supporting the whole person as evidenced by the separation of (1) clinical expertise generated by health professionals from patient expertise, and (2) patients’ quantified data from narrative experiences. Such separation in the design of these systems can lead to limitations in addressing patients’ interwoven medical and personal concerns. We discuss dilemmas and design implications for supporting the whole person in online patient communities.

Title: Adaptation as Design: Learning from an EMR Deployment Study
Author list: Sun Young Park, Yunan Chen
Keywords: Health Care; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Office and Workplace; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User Studies
Abstract: We conducted an observational study in an Emergency Department (ED) to examine the adaptation process after deploying an Electronic Medical Records (EMR) system. We investigated how EMR was adapted to the complex clinical work environment and how doctors and nurses engaged in the adaptation process. In this paper, we present three cases in which ED clinicians designed workarounds in order to adapt to the new work practice. Our findings reveal a rich picture of ED clinicians’ active reinterpretation and modification of their work practice through their engagement with the system-in-use and its organizational and physical context. These findings call for the adaptation period in designing a social-technical system in healthcare settings to be critically considered as an active end-user design process, a negotiating process, and a re-routinized process.

Title: BiPad and BiTouch: Designing Bimanual Interaction for Hand-held Tablets
Author list: Julie Wagner, Stephane Huot, Wendy Mackay
Keywords: Interaction Design; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Prototyping; User Studies
Abstract: Despite the demonstrated benefits of bimanual interaction, most tablets use just one hand for interaction, to free the other for support. In a preliminary study, we identified five holds that permit simultaneous support and interaction, and noted that users frequently change position to combat fatigue. We present the BiTouch design space, which introduces a support function in the kinematic chain model for interacting with hand-held tablets, and BiPad, a toolkit we developed for creating bimanual tablet interaction. We ran a controlled experiment to explore how tablet orientation and hand position affect three novel techniques: bimanual taps, gestures and chords. Bimanual taps significantly out- performed all one-handed techniques in both landscape and portrait orientations; bimanual chords and gestures significantly outperformed all one-handed techniques in portrait mode; and thumbs outperformed fingers, but were more tir- ing and less stable. Together, BiPad and BiTouch offer new opportunities for bimanual interaction on hand-held tablets.

Title: The User as a Sensor: Navigating Users with Visual Impairments in Indoor Spaces using Tactile Landmarks
Author list: Navid Fallah, Ilias Apostolopoulos, Kostas Bekris, Eelke Folmer
Keywords: Universal (or Disability)  Access; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Transport; Virtual Reality
Abstract: Indoor navigation systems for users who are visually impaired typically rely upon expensive physical augmentation of the environment or expensive sensing equipment; consequently few systems have been implemented. We present an indoor navigation system called Navatar that allows for localization and navigation by exploiting the physical characteristics of indoor environments, taking advantage of the unique sensing abilities of users with visual impairments, and minimalistic sensing achievable with low cost accelerometers available in smartphones. Particle filters are used to estimate the user's location based on the accelerometer data as well as the user confirming the presence of anticipated tactile landmarks along the provided path. Navatar has a high possibility of large-scale deployment, as it only requires an annotated virtual representation of an indoor environment. A user study with six blind users detemines the accuracy of our approach and identifies several areas for improvement.

Title: Understanding Negotiation in Airtime Sharing in Low-income Microenterprises
Author list: Nithya Sambasivan, Edward Cutrell
Keywords: Empirical Methods, Qualitative
Abstract: Shared access to airtime is a prominent mode of connectivity access in the developing world. We seek to understand airtime sharing among low-income microenterprises in India (small, low-capital businesses, such as flower sellers and milkmen), that constitute 90% of the total enterprises in India. We introduce social negotiation as the foundation of airtime sharing. We highlight negotiation mechanisms in the microenterprise, showing how shared resources are used towards personal interests amidst tensions and value conflicts, by adapting, modifying, subverting, and repurposing airtime. We then explore the design space of airtime and bandwidth sharing in low-income communities, including designing for negotiation and improving readability of airtime.

Title: Personas and Decision Making in the Design Process: An Ethnographic Case Study
Author list: Erin Friess
Keywords: Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Ethnography; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Personas have become a well-lauded method to aid designers in keeping the needs of the intended user population at the forefront of the design process. However, few studies have ethnographically observed design teams that use personas, and fewer studies have looked specifically at how designers linguistically invoke personas in their decision-making sessions. This discourse analysis of the decision-making sessions of designers at a top tier design firm reveals that although the designers dedicate much time researching, developing, and refining personas, personas themselves make relatively few appearances in the designers’ language during decision-making sessions. This study shows that, for persuasive ends, these designers, who are advocates of personas, routinely use other less precise and more designer-centric linguistic mechanisms in lieu of personas. Despite the scarcity of personas in the decision-making sessions, this ethnographic case study also explores the value of personas for this team even when the personas are not explicitly linguistically invoked.

Title: Talking about Implications for Design in a Pattern Language
Author list: Sebastian Denef, David Keyson
Keywords: Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Ethnography
Abstract: In this paper we present our approach to capture and share knowledge from ethnographic field studies using a pattern language and thereby inform the design of ubiquitous computing. In our case, we studied frontline firefighting by observing the existing practice, by developing empathy through participation and by introducing new technology as triggering artifacts. Applying grounded theory, we distilled our findings into a pattern language that describes core aspects of this practice and their interaction. In a workshop, we introduced the pattern language to developers who had no previous knowledge of this practice and, in follow-up interviews, confronted them with new technology proposals for firefighters. Our study shows that the pattern language, while not to be confused with a immutable description of the status quo or a direct path from ethnography to design, supports a reflective discussion of the novel technology and the fit with and potential impact on the existing practice.

Title: Improving Command Selection with CommandMaps
Author list: Joey Scarr, Andy Cockburn, Carl Gutwin, Andrea Bunt
Keywords: User Interface Design; User and Cognitive models
Abstract: Designers of GUI applications typically arrange commands in hierarchical structures, such as menus, due to screen space limitations. However, hierarchical organisations are known to slow down expert users. This paper proposes the use of spatial memory in combination with hierarchy flattening as a means of improving GUI performance. We demonstrate these concepts through the design of a command selection interface, called CommandMaps, and analyse its theoretical performance characteristics. We then describe two studies evaluating CommandMaps against menus and Microsoft’s Ribbon interface for both novice and experienced users. Results show that for novice users, there is no significant performance difference between CommandMaps and traditional interfaces – but for experienced users, CommandMaps are significantly faster than both menus and the Ribbon.

Title: The Role of Technology After the End of Life
Author list: Wendy Moncur, Jan Bikker, Elaine Kasket, John Troyer
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Computer-Mediated Communication; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social and Legal issues; Ethnography
Abstract: In this paper, we describe the collaborative processes and stakeholders involved in the period from when a person dies until they are laid to rest: the funeral, final disposition of the body, and (in some circumstances) victim identification. The rich mixture of technologies currently deployed during this brief period are categorized and critically analyzed. We then reflect on what our findings mean for the thanatosensitive design space and for the wider HCI community.

Title: Viewpoint: Empowering Communities with Situated Voting Devices
Author list: Nick Taylor, Justin Marshall, Alicia Blum-Ross, John Mills, Jon Rogers, Paul Egglestone, David Frohlich, Peter Wright, Patrick Olivier
Keywords: Virtual Community / Community Computing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Viewpoint is a public voting device developed to allow residents in a disadvantaged community to make their voices heard through a simple, lightweight interaction. This was intended to open a new channel of communication within the community and increase community members' perception of their own efficacy. Local elected officials and community groups were able to post questions on devices located in public spaces, where residents could vote for one of two responses. Question authors were subsequently required to post a response indicating any actions to be taken. Following a two-month trial, we present our experiences and contribute a number of dimensions impacting the effectiveness of public democracy tools, including credibility, efficacy and format.

Title: "panavi"": Recipe Medium with a Sensors-Embedded Pan for Domestic Users to Master Professional Culinary Arts
Author list: Daisuke Uriu, Mizuki Namai, Satoru Tokuhisa, Ryo Kashiwagi, Masahiko Inamai, Naohito Okude
Keywords: Interaction Design; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Home; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Prototyping; User Studies; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Product Design; User Experience Design / Experience Design
Abstract: "panavi," a recipe medium, supports domestic users in managing temperature and pan movement properly based on each step of a recipe by understanding the cooking condition, giving feedback to users suitable for their specific situation. The panavi system consists of a sensors-embedded frying pan and a computer system with an information display monitor and projector, which senses and analyzes data such as the current temperature and pan movements, and provides suitable feedback through projected images, LEDs and vibration of the pan, text alerts and sounds from the computer. Using this system, users can master professional quality culinary arts in the domestic kitchen. This paper provides a design frame work model for a cooking support system for domestic users, describes our motivation, design process, implementation, and user study, which outlines the experiences of users of this new recipe medium. During development as a trial and error process, our design team designed prototypes and conducted cooking experiments several times in an adequately equipped kitchen. Our research contributes to the design research community by demonstrating how to design daily commodities as smart objects to enrich experiences in everyday life.

Title: 360° Panoramic Overviews for Location-Based Services
Author list: Alessandro Mulloni, Hartmut Seichter, Andreas Dünser, Patrick Baudisch, Dieter Schmalstieg
Keywords: User Interface Design; Context-Aware Computing; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: We investigate 360° panoramas as overviews to support users in the task of locating objects in the surrounding environment. Panoramas are typically visualized as rectangular photographs, but this does not provide clear cues for physical directions in the environment. In this paper, we conduct a series of studies with three different shapes: Rectangle, Circle and Cylinder; the last two shapes are chosen because they provide a clearer representation of the spatial mapping between panorama and environment. Our results show that good readability of the panorama is most important and that a clear representation of the spatial mapping plays a secondary role. This paper is the first to provide understanding on how users exploit 360° panoramic overviews to locate objects in the surrounding environment and how different design factors can affect user performance.

Title: Characterizing Web Use on Smartphones
Author list: Chad Tossell, Philip Kortum, Ahmad Rahmati, Clayton Shepard, Lin Zhong
Keywords: Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; World Wide Web and Hypermedia; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User Interface Design
Abstract: This study examined how the web is used on iPhones.  A naturalistic and longitudinal approach was used to capture real interactions in the wild. These data were characterized to understand visits and revisits of resources on the internet through native web applications and web browsers. Results extend previous work done on PCs to current-generation smartphones. Among our findings is that longitudinal use of web browsers decreased with time, web page revisitation through browsers occurred very infrequently (approximately 25% of URLs are revisited by each user), and that bookmarks were used sparingly to access web content. We discuss the design implications of the findings for future handheld mobile content and systems.

Title: Next Steps for Value Sensitive Design
Author list: Alan Borning, Michael Muller
Keywords: Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Questions of human values often arise in HCI research and practice.  Such questions can be difficult to address well, and a principled approach can clarify issues of both theory and practice.  One such approach is Value Sensitive Design (VSD), an established theory and method for addressing issues of values in a systematic and principled fashion in the design of information technology.  In this essay, we suggest however that the theory and at times the presentation of VSD overclaims in a number of key respects, with the result of inhibiting its more widespread adoption and appropriation.  We address these issues by suggesting four topics for next steps in the evolution of VSD: (1) tempering VSD’s position on universal values; (2) contextualizing existing and future lists of values that are presented as heuristics for consideration; (3) strengthening the voice of the participants in publications describing VSD investigations; and (4) making clearer the voice of the researchers.  We propose new or altered approaches for VSD that address these issues of theory, voice, and reportage.

Title: Appreciating plei-plei around mobiles: Lessons from Rah Island
Author list: Pedro Ferreira, Kristina Höök
Keywords: User Studies; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Interaction Design; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: The rapid growth and adoption of mobiles in the developing world has attracted much attention. We set out to explore the ways in which mobiles made their way into Rah Island for the first time ever. We were struck by their playful use - especially given the very limited infrastructure and cheap mobiles they had. Based on our findings, we discuss tensions between playfulness and utility - particularly relating to socio-economic benefits - concluding that playfulness in these settings needs to be taken seriously as seriously as in any other setting. Based on these findings, we formulated three design challenges when designing for play in similar settings: (1) intimate engagement with the materials of cheap ICT, (2) revisit design recommendations for playfulness to ensure that they can travel/translate into other cultures, and (3) the need to innovate with less costly alternatives.

Title: Discovery-based Games for Learning Software
Author list: Tao Dong, Mira Dontcheva, Diana Joseph, Karrie Karahalios, Mark Newman, Mark Ackerman
Keywords: E-Learning and Education; Interaction Design; User Studies
Abstract: We propose using discovery-based learning games to teach people how to use complex software. Specifically, we developed Jigsaw, a Photoshop learning game that asks players to solve virtual jigsaw puzzles using tools in Photoshop. We conducted an eleven-person lab study of the prototype, and found the game to be an effective learning medium that can complement demonstration-based tutorials. Not only did the participants learn about new tools and techniques, but they also recalled techniques that they used to know while they were actively engaged in solving the puzzles in Jigsaw.

Title: A Hidden "Shortcut" in Fitts' Law to Access the Effects of Movement Direction on 2D Pointing
Author list: Xinyong Zhang, Hongbin Zha
Keywords: Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User Interface Design
Abstract: Fitts' law is the most widely applied model in HCI. However, this model and its existing extensions are still limited for 2D pointing task especially when the effects of movement direction (¦È) remain. In this paper, we employ the conception of projection to account for the effects of target width (W) and height (H) on movement time so that we seamlessly integrate the four factors, i.e. ¦È, amplitude (A), W and H, into the new extension of Fitts' law, which can uncover not only the periodicity of the asymmetrical impacts of W and H with the variation of ¦È but also their interrelation. Carrying out two experiments, we have justified that the vertical projection of W and the horizontal projection of H in the line near the movement direction are the determinants of movement time. Finally, we offer recommendations for 2D pointing experiments and discuss the implications for interface designs.

Title: The Envisioning Cards: A Toolkit for Catalyzing Humanistic and Technical Imaginations
Author list: Batya Friedman, David Hendry
Keywords: Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: We introduce the Envisioning Cards – a versatile toolkit for attending to human values during design processes – and discus their early use. Drawing on almost twenty years of work in value sensitive design, the Envisioning Cards are built upon a set of four envisioning criteria: stakeholders, time, values, and pervasiveness.  Each card contains on one side a title and an evocative image related to the card theme; on the flip side, the card shows the envisioning criterion, elaborates on the theme, and provides a focused design activity. Reports from the field demonstrate use in a range of research and design activities including brainstorming, co-design, heuristic evaluation, and more.

Title: <Insert Image>, Helping the Legal Use of Creative Commons Images
Author list: Herkko Hietanen, Antti Salovaara, Kumaripaba Athukorala, yefeng liu
Keywords: Social and Legal issues; Database access / Information Retrieval; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; Content Strategy / Content Creation
Abstract: Media creation applications cater poorly for one of the most common use cases: the situation when users would need media which they do not possess and for which they are unwilling to pay. Finding and using externally produced media is currently a cumbersome process. Often users just locate the content using a search engine, copy it to their work, cross their fingers and hope that copyrights are not infringed in the process. While authors have made available hundreds of millions of images with permissive licenses, the license terms are too complicated for users to follow. In our studies we found out that even the well-intending users failed to respect copyrights in simple image reuse situations. We introduce an Open Media Retrieval model for remedying this problem, and exemplify it with prototypes that access various legal image sources directly within the creative work flow and provide automatic credits to the authors.

Title: Comparing Averages in Time Series Data
Author list: Michael Correll, Danielle Albers, Steven Franconeri, Michael Gleicher
Keywords: Visualization; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Visual System Design / Visual Design; Perceptual & Vision-based UIs
Abstract: Visualizations often seek to aid viewers in assessing the big picture in the data, that is, to make judgements about aggregate properties of the data. In this paper, we present an empirical study of a representative aggregate judgement task: finding regions of maximum average in a series. We describe an experiment that assesses participants' ability to estimate averages and make judgements based on these averages. We show how a theory of perceptual averaging suggests a visual design other than the typically-used linegraph, and confirm that this color encoding significantly outperforms the standard practice. Our experiment also provides additional evidence for this perceptual averaging theory.

Title: ICT4A: Adaptation to the collapse of a complex society
Author list: Bill Tomlinson, M. Six Silberman, Donald Patterson, Eli Blevis, Yue Pan
Keywords: Sustainability; Social and Legal issues; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design
Abstract: Research in many fields argues that contemporary global industrial civilization will not persist indefinitely in its current form, and may, like many past human societies, eventually collapse. Arguments in environmental studies, anthropology, and other fields indicate that this transformation could begin within the next half-century. While imminent collapse is far from certain, it is prudent to consider now how to develop sociotechnical systems for use in these scenarios. We introduce the notion of Information & Communication Technologies for Adaptation (ICT4A) to denote the study, design, and development of sociotechnical systems in the abundant present for use in a future of scarcity, as a complement to ICT4D and mitigation-oriented sustainable HCI. We draw on a variety of literatures to offer a set of relevant concepts and articulate the relationships among them to orient and evaluate ICT4A work. Observing that ICT4A poses a unique class of cross-cultural design problems, we sketch the design space of ICT4A and provide a variety of example projects. We explore points of connection and distinction between ICT4A and sustainable HCI, ICT4D, and crisis informatics. Finally, we discuss next steps and comment on the potential value of ICT4A work even in the event that collapse never occurs.

Title: Interaction, Energy, and Emerging Energy Systems
Author list: James Pierce, Eric Paulos
Keywords: Sustainability; Home
Abstract: Motivated by a recent surge of research related to energy and sustainability within our field, this paper presents a review of energy-related work within HCI as well as from academic, government and industry literature outside of HCI. Our review of energy-related HCI research identifies a central cluster of work focused on electricity consumption feedback (ECF). Our review of literature outside of HCI highlights a number of emerging energy systems trends of strong relevance to HCI and interaction design, including smart grid, demand response and distributed generation technologies. We conclude by outlining a range of opportunities for HCI to engage with the experiential, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of these emerging systems, including highlighting new areas for ECF research as well as areas that move beyond our field’s current focus on energy feedback displays to increase awareness and motivate individual conservation behavior.

Title: Undesigning technology?:  Considering the negation of design by design
Author list: James Pierce
Keywords: Sustainability
Abstract: Motivated by substantive concerns over the limitations and negative effects of technology, this paper inquires into the negation of technology as an explicit and intentional aspect of design research within HCI. Building on theoretical constructs from areas including design theory, philosophy and social theory, this paper articulates a theoretical framework for conceptualizing the intentional negation of technology (i.e., the undesign of technology) in terms of its scope and scale, ranging from the inhibition of particular uses of technology to the total erasure or foreclosure of technology. I then expand on the framework by articulating several additional areas of undesigning, including self-inhibition, exclusion, removal, replacement, restoration and safeguarding. In conclusion, I offer a scheme for addressing questions concerning the disciplinary scope and boundaries of undesign activity within HCI, as well as some suggestions for ways that undesigning may be more strongly incorporated within HCI research concerned with design.

Title: “We’ve Bin Watching You” – Designing for Reflection and Social Persuasion to Promote Sustainable Lifestyles
Author list: Anja Thieme, Jack Weeden, Julia Miebach, Rob Comber, Nicole Kraemer, Shaun Lawson, Patrick Olivier
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Home; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; Sustainability
Abstract: BinCam is a social persuasive system to motivate reflection and behavioral change in the food waste and recycling habits of young adults. The system replaces an existing kitchen refuse bin and automatically logs disposed of items through digital images captured by a smart phone installed on the underside of the bin lid. Captured images are uploaded to a BinCam application on Facebook where they can be explored by all users of the BinCam system. Engagement with BinCam is designed to fit into the existing structure of users‟ everyday life, with the intention that reflection on waste and recycling becomes a playful and shared group activity. Results of a case study reveal an increase in both users‟ awareness of, and reflection about, their waste management and their motivation to improve their waste-related skills. With BinCam, we also explore informational and normative social influences as a source of change (e.g. socially evoked feelings of „guilt‟ for non-recycling or the disposal of food), which has to date been relatively underexplored in persuasive HCI. Design implications for reflection and social persuasion are proposed.

Title: Revisiting the Jacquard Loom: Reflections on the materiality of digital machinery
Author list: Jakob Tholander, Martin Jonsson, Ylva Fernaeus
Keywords: Interaction Design; End-user Programming; Tangible UIs; Sustainability
Abstract: In the recent developments of human computer interaction, one central challenge has been to find and to explore alternatives to the legacy of the desktop computer paradigm for interaction design. To investigate this issue further we have conducted an analysis on a fascinating piece of machinery often referred to as one of the predecessors of the modern day computer, the Jacquard loom. In analysing the Jacquard loom we look at qualities in design and interaction from some different perspectives: how historical tools, crafts, and practices can inform interaction design, the role of physicality, materiality, and whole-body interaction in order to rethink some current conceptions of interaction and design of computational devices.

Title: Steampunk as Design Fiction
Author list: Joshua Tanenbaum, Karen Tanenbaum, Ron Wakkary
Keywords: Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Interaction Design; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design; Sustainability
Abstract: In this paper we look at the Steampunk movement and consider its relevance as a design strategy for HCI and interaction design. Based on a study of online practices of Steampunk, we consider how, as a design fiction, Steampunk provides an explicit model for how to physically realize an ideological and imagined world through design practice.  We contend that the practices of DIY and appropriation that are evident in Steampunk design provide a useful set of design strategies and implications for HCI.

Title: Writing the Experience of Information Retrieval:  Digital Collection Design as a Form of Dialogue
Author list: Melanie Feinberg
Keywords: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Information Architecture; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Interaction Design
Abstract: In the context of digital libraries and other online resource collections, the substance of interaction is generated to a large degree through the selection, description, organization, and arrangement of the aggregated items. Within information studies, researchers [such as 29, 7] have shown how individual events of selection and description inevitably form judgments about the collected materials. This paper describes a process in which designers purposefully use the elements of selection, description, organization, and arrangement to “write” a resource collection as a form of rhetorical expression. The design process was implemented in two classroom settings. In the more successful second implementation, the role of the audience in structuring a rhetorical interaction was emphasized, and collection design was conceptualized as designing a dialogue between author and audience. The formalized critique of existing collection designs was a key element in enabling this dialogic orientation.

Title: Touch Typing using Thumbs: Understanding the Effect of Mobility and Hand Posture
Author list: Hugo Nicolau, Joaquim Jorge
Keywords: User Studies; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies
Abstract: Mobile touch devices have become increasingly popular, yet typing on virtual keyboards whilst walking is still an overwhelming task. In this paper we analyze; firstly, the negative effect of walking on text-input performance, particularly the users’ main difficulties and error patterns. We focused our research on thumb typing, since this is a commonly used technique to interact with touch interfaces. Secondly, we analyze how these effects can be compensated by two-hand interaction and increasing target size. We asked 22 participants to input text under three mobility conditions (seated, slow walking, and normal walking) and three hand conditions (one-hand/portrait, two-hand/portrait, and two-hand/landscape). Results show that independently of hand condition, mobility significantly decreased input quality, leading to specific error patterns. Moreover, it was shown that target size can compensate the negative effect of walking, while two-hand interaction does not provide additional stability or input accuracy. We finish with implications for future designs.

Title: Legible, are you sure ? an experimentation based typographical design in safety-critical context
Author list: Jean-Luc VINOT, Sylvie ATHENES
Keywords: Visualization; Industrial Design; Usability Testing and Evaluation; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design
Abstract: Designing Safety-critical IHM entails proving safety and operational usability of each component. To achieve this purpose, needs have to be carefully analyzed and translated into requirements leading to design principles. Prototypes following the previously defined principles can then be created, experimentally evaluated and accordingly altered until a final product is reached. In this paper, we present a research project whose goal is the creation of a new typeface to display textual information future aircraft HMI. In our study, after an initial task analysis leading to the definition of specific needs, requirements and design principles, the design constantly evolves from an iterative cycle of design and experimentation. We present three experiments (laboratory and cockpit) used mainly to validate initial choices and fine-tune font properties. Results also allowed us to define ranges of values of available choices to ensure compliance across changing requirements.

Title: A Comparative Evaluation of Finger and Pen Stroke Gestures
Author list: Huawei Tu, Xiangshi Ren, Shumin Zhai
Keywords: Tactile & Haptic UIs; Input and Interaction Technologies; Pen-based UIs
Abstract: This paper reports an empirical investigation in which participants produced a set of stroke gestures with varying degrees of complexity and in different target sizes using both the finger and the pen. The recorded gestures were then analyzed according to multiple measures characterizing many aspects of stroke gestures. Our findings were as follows: (1) Finger drawn gestures were quite different to pen drawn gestures in basic measures including size ratio and average speed. Finger drawn gestures tended to be larger and faster than pen drawn gestures. They also differed in shape geometry as measured by, for example, aperture of closed gestures, intersecting points deviation and corner shape distance; (2) Pen drawn gestures and finger drawn gestures were similar in several measures including articulation time, indicative angle difference, axial symmetry and proportional shape distance; (3) There were interaction effects between gesture implement (finger vs. pen) and target gesture size and gesture complexity. Our findings show that half of the features we tested were performed well enough by the finger. This finding suggests that "finger friendly" systems should exploit these features when designing finger interfaces and avoid using the other features in which the finger does not perform as well as the pen.

Title: Investigating the presence, form and behavior of virtual possessions in the context of a teen bedroom
Author list: William Odom, John Zimmerman, Jodi Forlizzi, Hajin Choi, Stephanie Meier, Angela Park
Keywords: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Home; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards)
Abstract: Over the past several years, people have acquired more and more virtual possessions. While virtual possessions are becoming ubiquitous, little work exists to inform designers on how these growing collections should be displayed and how they should behave. We generated four design concepts that advance the form and behavior of these digital artifacts within the context of a teen bedroom. We then conducted speed dating sessions with 14 teenagers to explore how these new forms and behaviors influence perceptions of value. Sessions revealed insights into how new technologies might better support self-exploration and reflection, as well as how they could potentially complicate identity construction processes. Findings are interpreted to detail opportunity areas and value tensions to guide future research and practice in this emerging space.

Title: Technology Heirlooms? Considerations for  Passing Down and Inheriting Digital Materials
Author list: William Odom, Richard Banks, David Kirk, Richard Harper, Siân Lindley, Abi Sellen
Keywords: User Experience Design / Experience Design; Home; Interaction Design
Abstract: Material artifacts are passed down as a way of sustaining relationships and family history. However, new issues are emerging as families are increasingly left with the digital remains of their loved ones. We designed three devices to encourage critically reflection on how digital materials might be passed down, lived with and inherited in the future. We conducted in-home interviews with 8 families using the devices as prompts to provoke discussion about how technology might support (or complicate) their existing practices. Sessions revealed families desired to treat their archives in ways not fully supported by technology as well as potential tensions that could emerge. Findings are interpreted to detail design and research considerations for future work in this emerging space.

Title: Homeless Young People on Social Network Sites
Author list: Jill Woelfer, David Hendry
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Social and Legal issues; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: This paper reports on the use of social network sites (MySpace and Facebook) by homeless young people, an extraordinary user population, made so in part by its vulnerability. Twenty-three participants of diverse ethnicities, 11 women and 12 men (mean age, 21.7 years), were interviewed in same-sexed discussion groups of four participants each. The interviews consisted of questions about the uses, benefits, and harms of social network sites and how people present themselves online. Qualitative analysis of the discussion group transcripts shows how young people explore their identities, cultivate and exploit social ties, experience interpersonal tensions, manage incompatible audiences, and respond to shifting affiliations and transitions. From this analysis, implications for social intervention and technical design are presented, focused on maintaining ties with pro-social family and friends and with maintaining separation between communication spheres of incompatible audiences. This work contributes to the growing literature on vital, deeply human experiences that have become associated with social network sites.

Title: Interactive Visualization for Low Literacy Users: From Lessons Learnt To Design
Author list: Neesha Kodagoda, William Wong, Chris Rooney, Nawaz Khan
Keywords: Visualization; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Usability Testing and Evaluation; Visual Design; User Studies; Visual System Design / Visual Design; Usability Research; User Interface Design
Abstract: This paper aims to address the problems low literacy (LL) users face when searching for information online.  The first part of this paper summarizes the problems that LL user’s face, and establishes a set of design principles for interfaces suitable for LL users. This is followed by a description of how these design principles are mapped to a novel interface for interactive data retrieval. The interface was realized into a working system and evaluated against a traditional web interface for both high literacy (HL) and LL users. The suitability of the designs was analyzed using performance data, subjective feedback and an observational analysis. The findings from the study suggest that LL users perform better and prefer the proposed designs over a traditional web interface.

Title: Tangible Remote Controllers for Wall-Size Displays
Author list: Yvonne Jansen, Pierre Dragicevic, Jean-Daniel Fekete
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Visualization; Tangible UIs
Abstract: We explore the use of customizable tangible remote controllers for interacting with wall-size displays. Such controllers are especially suited to visual exploration tasks where users need to move to get overviews or details of complex visualizations.
