The approach can be implemented using consumer depth cameras because (1) shoes offer large distinct features such as color, (2) shoes naturally align themselves with the ground, giving the system a well-defined perspective and thus reduced ambiguity. We report a simple study in which Bootstrapper recognized participants from a database of 18 users with 89% accuracy, based on a single observed frame.

Title: CapStones: Sensing Stacks of Building Blocks, Dials and Sliders on Capacitive Touch Screens
Author list: Liwei Chan, Stefanie Müller, Anne Roudaut, Patrick Baudisch
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing
Abstract: Recent research proposes augmenting capacitive touch pads with tangible objects, enabling a new generation of mobile applications enhanced with tangible objects, such as game pieces and tangible controllers. In this paper, we extend the concept to capacitive tangibles consisting of multiple parts, such as stackable gaming pieces and tangible widgets with moving parts. We achieve this using a system of wires and connectors inside each block that causes the capacitance of the bottom-most block to reflect the entire assembly. We demonstrate three types of tangibles, called CapStones, Zebra Dials and Zebra Sliders that work with current consumer hardware and investigate what designs may become possible as touchscreen hardware evolves.

Title: Rock-Paper-Fibers: bringing physical affordance to mobile touch devices
Author list: Frederik Rudeck, Patrick Baudisch
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing
Abstract: Since the surfaces of touchpads and touch screens are feature-less, they offer little affordance. To alleviate this, researchers have proposed overlaying touch controls with custom shapes, such as DataTiles. Unfortunately, tiles require space, limiting this approach to tabletop-size devices. \  \ In this paper, we explore how to bring custom-shaped physical controls to mobile touch devices. To achieve the required smallness we eliminate tiles—instead users reshape the device itself. For efficiency, users interact bimanually: one hand reshapes the device; the other hand operates the resulting widget. \  \ We present a prototype that achieves deformability using a bundle of optical fibers, demonstrate an audio player and a simple video game each featuring multiple widgets and demonstrate how to support applications that require responsiveness by adding mechanical wedges and clamps. \

Title: The Impact of Three Interfaces for 360-Degree Video on Spatial Cognition
Author list: Wutthigrai Boonsuk, Stephen Gilbert, Jonathan Kelly
Keywords: User Interface Design; Usability Testing and Evaluation; Visual System Design / Visual Design; Perceptual & Vision-based UIs
Abstract: In this paper, we describe an experiment designed to evaluate the effectiveness of three interfaces for surveillance or remote control using live 360-degree video feeds from a person or vehicle in the field.  Video feeds are simulated using a game engine.  While locating targets within a 3D terrain using a 2D 360-degree interface, participants indicated perceived egocentric directions to targets and later placed targets on an overhead view of the terrain.  Interfaces were compared based on target finding and map placement performance.  Results suggest 1) non-seamless interfaces with visual boundaries facilitate spatial understanding, 2) correct perception of self-to-object relationships is not correlated with understanding object-to-object relationships within the environment, and 3) increased video game experience corresponds with better spatial understanding of an environment observed in 360-degrees.  This work can assist designers of panoramic video systems in designing the optimal interface for observation and teleoperation of remote systems.

Title: Enabling Concurrent Dual Views on Common LCD Screens
Author list: Seokhwan Kim, Xiang Cao, Haimo Zhang, Desney Tan
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies
Abstract: Researchers have explored a variety of technologies that enable a single display to simultaneously present different content when viewed from different angles or by different people. These displays provide new functionality such as personalized views for multiple users, privacy protection, and stereoscopic 3D displays. However, current multi-view displays rely on special hardware, thus significantly limiting their availability to consumers and adoption in everyday scenarios. In this paper, we present a pure software solution (i.e. with no hardware modification) that allows us to pre-sent two independent views concurrently on the most wide-ly used and affordable type of LCD screen, namely Twisted Nematic (TN). We achieve this by exploiting a technical limitation of the technology which causes these LCDs to show varying brightness and color depending on the viewing angle. We describe our technical solution as well as demonstrate example applications in everyday scenarios.

Title: Assisting Hand Skill Transfer of Tracheal Intubation Using Outer-Covering Haptic Display
Author list: Vivol Yem, Hideaki Kuzuoka, Ryota Shibusawa, Naomi Yamashita, Hiroaki Yano, Jun Yamashita
Keywords: Tactile & Haptic UIs; Virtual Reality; Multi-modal interfaces
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel haptic display called Outer-Covering Haptic Display (OCHD), that supports effective training of hand skills that require strength. Adopting tracheal intubation training as an example, we show the difficulty of teaching a novice to manipulate a laryngoscope. Although previous training systems tackled the issue by presenting force to the learner’s palm by directly actuating the laryngoscope, this approach is sometimes ineffective because learners typically have difficulty sensing the haptic feedback from the laryngoscope when they are holding it tightly. Thus, we propose a different approach (OCHD) that effectively guides the novice’s hand by presenting force to the back of his/her hand as if an expert is holding it. A preliminary experiment showed that OCHD effectively guides users with less actuator drive force than cases where a laryngoscope is directly actuated.

Title: Augmented Perception of Satiety: Controlling Food Consumption by Changing Apparent Size of Food with Augmented Reality
Author list: Takuji Narumi, Yuki Ban, Takashi Kajinami, Tomohiro Tanikawa, Michitaka Hirose
Keywords: Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Health Care; Interaction Design
Abstract: The main contribution of this paper is to realize a method to modify our perception of satiety and control our nutrition intake by changing apparent size of food with augmented reality. To decrease the number of obese people, we focus on controlling energy intake implicitly without any effort by using human-computer interaction techniques.  \  \ Our hypothesis is that the ambiguity of the perception of satiety can be applied to control our energy intake. Recent psychological studies have revealed that the consumption volume of food is influenced not only its real volume but also external factors during eating. Based on this knowledge, we aimed to control perception of satiety which is gained from the same amount of food by changing its apparent size and proposed a method for food-volume augmentation using real-time shape deformation. Through an experiment, we suggested that we can control the perception of satiety and nutrition intake. \

Title: Deformable Input Device with Variable Stiffness
Author list: Yusuke Nakagawa, KAMIMURA AKIYA, Yoichiro Kawaguchi
Keywords: Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies; Interaction Design; Tactile & Haptic UIs
Abstract: This paper introduces a novel deformable device with variable stiffness for mobile phones. We implement two features in this device. The first is that the user should be able to use several deformation-based gestures. This input method allows the user to interact with a small device in various different ways. The other feature is that the device should provide information through haptic feedback for devices with a small display area. Our device changes its stiffness to provide haptic feedback to a user. These two features are appropriate for mobile phones to enlarge its application. To implement these features we propose a device that uses only shape memory alloy (SMA) wires as the actuator. Shape memory alloy wire is extremely flexible, making it suitable for deformable user interfaces. We found that shape memory alloy wires work as both the actuator by varying their stiffness with the change being felt by a user and as external input sensors. This study addresses further development of deformable user interfaces.

Title: Touché: Enhancing Touch Interaction on Humans, Screens, Liquids, and Everyday Objects
Author list: Munehiko Sato, Ivan Poupyrev, Chris Harrison
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; Context-Aware Computing; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments
Abstract: We present Touché, a novel sensing technology that adds touch sensitivity to the real world easily and inexpensively. Touché implements a novel Swept Frequency Capacitive Sensing technique, that can not only detect a touch event, but also recognize complex configurations of the human hand and body. Such contextual information significantly enhances touch interaction in a broad range of application scenarios, from conventional capacitive touchscreens to unique contexts and materials. For example, in our explorations, we add touch and gesture sensitivity to the human body and liquids. We demonstrate the rich capabilities of Touché with five example setups from different application domains and conduct experimental studies that show gestures classification accuracies of 99% are achievable with our technology, demonstrating immediate feasibility.

Title: TeleAdvisor: A Versatile Augmented Reality Tool for Remote Assistance
Author list: Pavel Gurevich, Joel Lanir, Benjamin Cohen, Ran Stone
Keywords: Augmented Reality; Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments
Abstract: TeleAdvisor is a novel solution designed to support remote assistance tasks in many real-world scenarios. It consists of a video camera and a small projector mounted at the end of a tele-operated robotic arm. This enables a remote helper to view and interact with the workers’ workspace, while controlling the point of view. It also provides the worker with a hands-free transportable device to be placed anywhere in his or her environment. Active tracking of the projection space is used in order to reliably correlate between the camera’s view and the projector space.

Title: Asking the Right Person: Supporting Expertise Selection in the Enterprise
Author list: Svetlana Yarosh, Tara Matthews, Michelle Zhou
Keywords: Office and Workplace; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Social Computing and Social Navigation; User Studies
Abstract: Expertise selection is the process of choosing an expert from a list of possible recommendations. This is an im- portant and nuanced step in expertise location that has not received a great deal of attention. Through a lab-based, con- trolled investigation with 35 enterprise workers, we found that presenting additional information about each expert in the recommendation results led the participants to make quicker and better-informed selections. We also asked par- ticipants to rate the type of information that might be most useful for expertise selection on a paper prototype contain- ing 36 types of potentially helpful information. We identi- fied sixteen types of such information that may be most useful to obtain and display when recommending experts.

Title: MirageTable: Freehand Interaction with Virtual and Digitized Objects on a Spatial Augmented Reality Tabletop
Author list: Hrvoje Benko, Ricardo Jota, Andrew Wilson
Keywords: Augmented Reality; Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Input and Interaction Technologies; 3D Interaction; Perceptual & Vision-based UIs
Abstract: Instrumented with a single depth camera, a stereoscopic projector, and a curved screen, MirageTable is an interactive system designed to merge real and virtual worlds into a single spatially registered experience on top of a table. Our depth camera tracks the user’s eyes and performs a real time capture of both the shape and the appearance of any object placed in front of the camera (including user’s body and hands). This real-time capture enables: 1) perspective stereoscopic 3D visualizations to a single user that account for deformations caused by physical objects on the table, and 2) high-fidelity freehand interactions with virtual objects in much the same way users manipulate real world objects: through physically realistic behaviors and without any gloves, trackers, or instruments. We illustrate these unique capabilities through three application examples: virtual 3D model creation, interactive gaming with real and virtual objects, and a 3D teleconferencing experience that not only presents a 3D view of a remote person, but also a seamless 3D shared task space. We performed a preliminary evaluation of the 3D image quality in our system given a variety of background geometries and colors. Our results show that physical discontinuities (gaps, drops) in the background had the most negative effect on users’ depth perception and preference, even though, the change in background color objectively impacted the object’s appearance the most.

Title: The Impact of Communication Structure on New Product Development Outcomes
Author list: Marcelo Cataldo, Kate Ehrlich
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Office and Workplace; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: New product development teams face important challenges to their performance due to the novelty of the work and the need to rapidly develop shared knowledge and goals. However, little is known about the relationship between the structural properties of communication and performance outcomes of productivity and quality. This study examined the effect of communication structure, specifically hierarchical and small-world structures on the delivery performance and quality outcomes of a large-scale new product development project. Our longitudinal analyses revealed that structuring communication patterns in a hierarchical manner significantly improves delivery performance. However, we found that hierarchical communication structures have a significant detrimental effect on quality while small-world communication structures improved the quality outcomes of development teams. We discuss the implications of these results for tradeoffs in communication structure.

Title: A Longitudinal Study of Facebook, LinkedIn, & Twitter Use
Author list: Anne Archambault, Jonathan Grudin
Keywords: Organizational Culture / Organizational Planning; Computer-Mediated Communication; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Social and Legal issues
Abstract: We conducted four annual comprehensive annual surveys of social networking in a large technology company between 2008 and 2011. Our focus is on how employees use these tools and whether they consider then useful for organizational communication and information-gathering. Our study is longitudinal and based on random sampling. Over a period when social networking went from being a niche activity to widely adopted, the behaviors and concerns of employees at our site changed. Some activities show signs of plateauing in 2011. The tremendous growth in use and acceptance was not uniform, with differences based on gender, age and other characteristics.

Title: Interchangeability of Computer and Paper Based Questionnaires in Gathering Computer Experience Data from Young Children
Author list: Akiyo Kano, Janet Read
Keywords: Children; Input and Interaction Technologies; Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); Software architecture and engineering
Abstract: The study compares self-reported computer experience (CE) obtained from children in computer-assisted and paper-and-pencil self-administered questionnaires. Twenty primary school children aged between 8 and 9 years completed a set of CE questions in both forms of administration in a Latin-square order. Findings show that young children can use both method, and that they are able to answer a computer-based questionnaire just as accurately as paper-based questionnaire.

Title: Online Gaming Motivations Scale: Development and Validation
Author list: Nick Yee, Nicolas Ducheneaut, Les Nelson
Keywords: User Studies; Entertainment; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: Understanding gaming motivations is important given the growing trend of incorporating game-based mechanisms in non-gaming applications. In this paper, we describe the development and validation of an online gaming motivations scale based on a 3-factor model. Data from 2,072 US participants and 645 Hong Kong and Taiwan participants is used to provide a cross-cultural validation of the developed scale. Analysis of actual in-game behavioral metrics is also provided to demonstrate predictive validity of the scale.

Title: Through the Azerothian Looking Glass: Mapping In-Game Preferences to Real World Demographics
Author list: Nick Yee, Nicolas Ducheneaut, Han-Tai Shiao, Les Nelson
Keywords: User Studies; Entertainment; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: Examining how in-game behavior preferences map onto real world demographics provides important empirically-derived insights into how to match game-based mechanisms to target demographic segments. Using behavioral and demographic data from 1,037 World of Warcraft players, we used multiple regressions to provide this mapping. Given current interest in “gamifying” applications, we believe these findings are relevant for both gaming and non-gaming research.

Title: A Hybrid Mass Participation Approach to Mobile Software Trials
Author list: Alistair Morrison, Donald McMillan, Stuart Reeves, Scott Sherwood, Matthew Chalmers
Keywords: User Studies; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing
Abstract: User trials of mobile applications have followed a steady march out of the lab, and progressively further ‘into the wild’, recently involving ‘app store’-style releases of software to the general public. We examine the literature on these mass participation systems and identify a number of reported difficulties, which we aim to address with a hybrid methodology combining a global software release with a concurrent local trial. A phone–based game, World Cup Predictor, was created to explore the uptake and use of ad hoc peer-to-peer networking, and evaluated using our hybrid trial method, combining a small-scale local trial (11 users) with a ‘mass participation’ trial (over 10,000 users). Our hybrid method allows for locally observed findings to be verified, for patterns in globally collected data to be explained and addresses ethical issues raised by the mass participation approach. We note trends in the local trial that did not appear in the larger scale deployment, and which would therefore have led to misleading results were the application trialled using ‘traditional’ methods alone. Based on this study and previous experience, we provide a set of guidelines to researchers working in this area.

Title: Interaction Proxemics and Image Use in Neurosurgery
Author list: Helena Mentis, Kenton O'Hara, Abi Sellen, Riki Trivedi
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Context-Aware Computing; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Health Care; Office and Workplace; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Interaction Design
Abstract: Within medical settings there is a growing interest in exploring touchless interaction technologies. The primary motivation here is to avoid contact during interaction so as to maintain asepsis.  However, there is another important property of touchless interaction that has significant implications for their use within such settings – namely that interaction behaviour is spatially distal from the device being interacted with.  To further understand these implications we present fieldwork observations of work practice in neurosurgery theatres.  Drawing on the notion of interaction proxemics and the theory of F-formations, our analysis articulates the spatial organization of collaborative work practices and interaction in these settings.  From this understanding of spatial practices, we discuss opportunities and difficulties relating to the design of touchless interaction technologies for these settings.

Title: Supporting Face-To-Face Communication Between Clinicians and Children with Chronic Headaches Through a Zoomable Multi-Touch App
Author list: Juan Pablo Hourcade, Martha Driessnack, Kelsey Huebner
Keywords: Health Care; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Pen and Tactile Input; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Children; Universal (or Disability)  Access; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Interaction Design; Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Interface Design; Pen-based UIs; Tactile & Haptic UIs; Creativity Support Tools
Abstract: Chronic headaches are one of the top five health problems for young children in the United States, negatively affecting their quality of life and learning opportunities. A clear understanding of children’s headache characteristics is crucial for delivering appropriate treatment. However,  current data collection methods were designed for adults often resulting in insufficient information. In this paper we present a novel method to help children communicate with health care providers and researchers about their headaches. It augments an existing child-centric method called Draw-and-Tell Conversation, which has already been shown to provide more actionable information from children than standard data collection methods.  It does so by enabling children to draw their symptoms on a zoomable drawing application, giving them the ability to provide more details and context than on paper. We present a study conducted with nineteen children aged 7 to 12 suggesting that children provided more information about their headaches when using the zoomable drawing application than when drawing on paper. This study provides a rare example of a mobile device used to enhance face-to-face interactions and contributes evidence of a specific benefit of zoomable user interfaces.

Title: Exploring Problems of Data Mobility and Reuse
Author list: Mark Hartswood, Rob Procter, Lilian Blot, Stuart Anderson, Mark Rouncefield, Roger Slack
Keywords: Database access / Information Retrieval; E-Learning and Education; Health Care; Office and Workplace; Ethnography; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: This paper explores some of the problems encountered in \ using a data archive to build tools to facilitate the training \ of mammogram readers. We detail our experiences of \ taking materials (images, case notes) created as part of the \ work of breast cancer screening and using them as \ resources for training. We formulate some general lessons \ concerning data mobility and reuse, where the ‘data’ \ consists of rich ensembles of data and artefacts drawn from \ complex professional settings.

Title: ShutEye: Encouraging Awareness of Healthy Sleep Recommendations with a Mobile, Peripheral Display
Author list: Jared Bauer, Sunny Consolvo, Benjamin Greenstein, Jonathan Schooler, Eric Wu, Nathaniel F Watson, Julie Kientz
Keywords: Health Care; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Sleep is a basic physiological drive that is essential for good health. However, 40 million people in the U.S. are diagnosed with sleep disorders, with many others not yet diagnosed. To help address this problem, we developed an application, ShutEye, which provides a peripheral display on the wallpaper of the user’s mobile phone to promote awareness about recommended activities that promote good sleep quality. Based on preferences about the user’s desired bedtime and activities—for example, consuming caffeine or performing vigorous exercise—ShutEye displays guidance about when engaging in those activities is likely to affect sleep without requiring any explicit interaction from the user. In this paper, we describe ShutEye and results from a four-week field study with 12 participants. Results indicate that a simple, recommendation-based peripheral display can be a very low-effort but still effective method for improving awareness of healthy sleep habits. We also provide recommendations about designing peripheral displays and extend insights for designing health-based mobile applications.

Title: Health Promotion as Activism: Building Community Capacity to Affect Social Change
Author list: Andrea Parker, Vasudhara Kantroo, Hee Rin Lee, Miguel Osornio, Mansi Sharma, Rebecca Grinter
Keywords: Health Care; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
Abstract: As HCI researchers have designed tools to promote wellness, disease has often been approached as a general problem. In contrast, public health research has argued for an activist approach focused on how certain groups disproportionately experience disease and eliminating these disparities. Taking this activist stance, we examine how technology can reduce health inequalities by disrupting power relationships and helping communities pursue social change. We discuss our tool, Community Mosaic (CM), which allows individuals to share their healthy eating ideas with one another, as a means of advocating behavior change. Our results characterize how CM helped facilitate activism (i.e., collective efforts to counter local challenges to healthy living) and shift users’ attitudes regarding their role as advocates for health. We contribute to the field of HCI by using our findings to present a set of recommendations for future research focused on designing and evaluating health promotion tools using an activist lens.

Title: A Handle Bar Metaphor for Virtual Object Manipulation with Mid-Air Interaction
Author list: Peng Song, Wooi Boon Goh, William Hutama, Chi-Wing Fu, Xiaopei Liu
Keywords: Interaction Design; Input and Interaction Technologies; Visualization; User Interface Design; 3D Interaction
Abstract: Current mid-air interaction techniques to manipulate 3D virtual objects tend to assign separate roles and gestures to the left and right hands, making the bimanual gestures difficult to recall and preventing natural gestural interactions that can smoothly transit between translation, rotation, and scaling operations. A novel handle bar metaphor is proposed as an effective visual control metaphor between the user's hand gestures and the corresponding virtual object manipulation operations. It mimics a familiar situation of handling objects that are skewered with a bimanual handle bar. The use of relative 3D motion of the two hands to support the mid-air interaction design allows precise controllability with low resolution 3D scene acquisition systems that are low cost and widely available, such as the Microsoft Kinect sensor. A comprehensive repertoire of 3D manipulation operations is proposed to manipulate single objects, perform fast constrained rotation, and pack/align multiple objects along a line. Three user studies were devised to demonstrate the efficacy and intuitiveness of the proposed interaction techniques on different virtual manipulation scenarios.

Title: "You're Capped": Understanding the Effects of Bandwidth Caps on Broadband Use in the Home
Author list: Marshini Chetty, Richard Banks, A.J. Brush, Jonathan Donner, Rebecca Grinter
Keywords: Home; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User Studies
Abstract: Bandwidth caps, a limit on the amount of data users can upload and download in a month, are common globally for both home and mobile Internet access. With caps each bit of data consumed comes at a cost against a monthly quota or a running tab. Yet relatively little work has considered the implications of this usage-based pricing model on the user experience. In this paper, we present results from a qualitative study of households living with bandwidth caps. Our findings suggest home users grapple with three uncertainties regarding their bandwidth usage: invisible balances, mysterious processes, and multiple users. We discuss how these uncertainties impact their usage and describe the potential for better tools to help monitor and manage data caps. We conclude that as a community we need to cater for users under Internet cost constraints.

Title: The eLabBench in the Wild, Supporting Exploratory Science in the Biology Lab
Author list: Aurélien Tabard, Juan David Hincapié Ramos, Jakob Bardram
Keywords: User Studies; Pen and Tactile Input; Office and Workplace; Tangible UIs
Abstract: In this paper we present a field trial of the eLabBench, a digital tabletop-based laboratory bench designed to support the exploratory practices of biologists in the laboratory. The eLabBench allows biologists to organize personal information, capture experimental work for later access, and use a variety of computational resources directly at the lab bench. We deployed the eLabBench in a biology laboratory for 16 weeks, and invited seven biologists to run experiments on it. We report on how the biologists used the bench and how it fitted within their larger experimental process. The main impact of the eLabBench lies in the changes it sparked off in preparing, running and documenting lab experiments. By supporting computation at the bench and management of physical objects in the office, the eLabBench blurred the separation between office and laboratory work. Based on our observations, we discuss how interactive systems for laboratories such as the eLabBench can support a more exploratory or design-oriented way of ‘doing’ science.

Title: The Search Dashboard: Changing How People Search Using a Reflective Interface
Author list: Scott Bateman, Jaime Teevan, Ryen White
Keywords: Database access / Information Retrieval; World Wide Web and Hypermedia
Abstract: Most searchers do not know how to use Web search engines as effectively as possible. This is due, in part, to search en-gines not providing feedback about how search behavior can be improved. Because feedback is an essential part of learning, we created the Search Dashboard, which provides an interface for reflection on personal search behavior. The Dashboard aggregates and presents an individual’s search history and provides comparisons with that of archetypal expert profiles. Via a five-week study of 90 Search Dash-board users, we find that users are able to change aspects of their behavior to be more in line with that of the presented expert searchers. We also find that reflection can be beneficial, even without comparison, by changing participants’ views about their own search skills, what is possible with search, and what aspects of their behavior may influence search success. Our findings demonstrate a new way for search engines to help users modify their search behavior for positive outcomes.

Title: Characterizing Local Interests and Local Knowledge
Author list: Ryen White, Georg Buscher
Keywords: World Wide Web and Hypermedia; Database access / Information Retrieval; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: When searching for destinations and activities, the interests and knowledge of locals and non-locals may vary. In this paper, we compare and contrast the search-related interests of these two groups, and when they share a common inter-est (in our case, for restaurants), we analyze the quality of the venues they visit. We find differences in search interests depending on degree of local knowledge, and that locals generally select better quality venues than non-locals. These findings have implications for the design of search and recommendation systems that can personalize results to locals and leverage local knowledge to benefit non-locals.

Title: The SoundsRight CAPTCHA: An Improved Approach to Audio Human Interaction Proofs for Blind Users
Author list: Jonathan Lazar, Jinjuan Feng, Tim Brooks, Genna Melamed, Brian Wentz, Jon Holman, Abiodun Olalere, Nnanna Ekedebe
Keywords: Universal (or Disability)  Access; World Wide Web and Hypermedia; Usability Testing and Evaluation; Security
Abstract: In this paper we describe the development of a new audio CAPTCHA called the SoundsRight CAPTCHA, and the evaluation of the CAPTCHA with 20 blind users. Blind users cannot use visual CAPTCHAs, and it has been documented in the research literature that the existing audio CAPTCHAs have task success rates below 50% for blind users. The SoundsRight audio CAPTCHA presents a real time audio-based challenge in which the user is asked to identify a specific sound (for example the sound of a bell or a piano) from a series of 10 sounds that are played through the computer’s audio system. Evaluation results from three rounds of usability testing document that the task success rate was higher than 90% for blind users. Discussion, limitations, and suggestions for future research are also presented.

Title: "Yours is Better!" Participant Response Bias in HCI
Author list: Nicola Dell, Vidya Vaidyanathan, Indrani Medhi, Edward Cutrell, Bill Thies
Keywords: User Studies; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Internationalization / Localization; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design
Abstract: Although HCI researchers and practitioners frequently work with groups of people that differ significantly from themselves, little attention has been paid to the effects these differences have on the evaluation of HCI systems.  Via 450 interviews in Bangalore, India, we measure the response bias as participants provide feedback to researchers with varying social distances from themselves.  We find that respondents are twice as likely to prefer a technological artifact that they believe to be developed by the interviewer, even when the alternative is identical.  When the social distance between interviewer and participant increases to the point of needing a translator, the bias towards the interviewer's artifact increases to 5x.  In fact, the interviewer's artifact is preferred even when it is degraded to be obviously inferior to the alternative.  We conclude that participant response bias should receive more attention within the CHI community, especially when designing for underprivileged populations.

Title: Tell Me More? The Effects of Mental Model Soundness on Personalizing an Intelligent Agent
Author list: Todd Kulesza, Simone Stumpf, Margaret Burnett, Irwin Kwan
Keywords: Agents and Intelligent Systems; End-user Programming
Abstract: What does a user need to know to productively work with an intelligent agent? Intelligent agents and recommender systems are gaining widespread use, creating a need for end users to understand how these systems operate in order to allow users to personalize their agent’s behavior. This paper explores the effects of mental model soundness on such personalization by providing structural knowledge of a music recommender system in an empirical study. Our findings show that participants were able to quickly build sound mental models of the recommender system’s reasoning, and that participants who most improved their mental models during the study were significantly more likely to make the recommender operate to their satisfaction. Moreover, participants’ user experience did not suffer. These results suggest that by helping end users acquire an understanding of the system’s reasoning, intelligent agents may elicit more and better feedback, thus more closely aligning their output with each user’s intentions.

Title: Designing a Debugging Language for Cognitive Modelers with Natural Programming Plus
Author list: Christopher Bogart, Margaret Burnett, Scott Douglass, Hannah Adams, Rachel White
Keywords: Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); End-user Programming; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User and Cognitive models
Abstract: In this paper, we investigate how a debugging environment should support a population doing work at the core of HCI research: cognitive modelers.  In conducting this investigation, we also extended the original Natural Programming methodology (a user-centered design method for HCI researchers of programming environments); we call the new method Natural Programming Plus. Natural Programming Plus makes explicit a method for mapping the outcomes of NP’s empirical investigations to a language design. Its aim is to provide a concrete method for computer scientists uncomfortable with the design leap from empirical assessment of users’ needs to a language. The contributions of our work are therefore: (1) the new Natural Programming Plus methodology, (2) empirical evidence about the content and sequence of modelers’ information needs when debugging, and (3) a new, empirically derived, design specification for a debugging interaction language for cognitive modelers.

Title: Improving Scrolling Devices with  Document Length Dependent Gain
Author list: Andy Cockburn, Philip Quinn, Carl Gutwin, Stephen Fitchett
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Usability Testing and Evaluation
Abstract: We describe a method for applying gain to events reported by scrolling input devices such as scroll wheels. By treating document length as an input to our gain functions, the method allows rapid document traversal regardless of document length. It also allows slow and precise scroll control at shorter distances. An initial experiment is used to characterise four diverse scrolling input devices – a standard ‘notched’ scroll wheel, a high performance ‘inertia’ wheel, an isometric scrolling joystick, and a trackpad – and the results are used to calibrate several gain function parameters. A second experiment validates the method, showing that it allows faster scrolling in long and short documents than current scrolling-device gain methods, and that subjective preferences favour it.

Title: Is This What You Meant? Promoting Listening on the Web by Crowdsourcing Comment Summarization
Author list: Travis Kriplean, Michael Toomim, Jonathan Morgan, Alan Borning, Andrew Ko
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Virtual Community / Community Computing; Social and Legal issues
Abstract: Online discussion is increasingly central to public discourse and decision-making. While current interfaces such as blogs and forums are well designed for commenting and replying they provide little support for listening, which is known to be important for finding common ground. We contribute a design-oriented theoretical frame for supporting listening on the web, focusing on the design of a novel interface for listening called Reflect. Reflect creates a space next to every comment where people can summarize and restate points they hear the commenter making. We evaluate Reflect through deployments on Slashdot (a technology news site), Wikimedia’s Strategic Planning Initiative, a civic engagement effort in Seattle, Washington, and an A/B tested discussion deployed to Mechanical Turk. These deployments show that people use Reflect to restate comments and that people believe it changed the way they read and write comments, suggesting that listening interfaces may improve public discourse on the web.

Title: I did that! Measuring Users’ Experience of Agency in their own Actions
Author list: David Coyle, James Moore, Per Ola Kristensson, Paul Fletcher, Alan Blackwell
Keywords: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User Studies; User Interface Design
Abstract: Cognitive neuroscience defines the sense of agency as the experience of controlling one’s own actions and, though this control, affecting the external world. We believe that the sense of personal agency is a key factor in how people experience interactions with technology. This paper draws on theoretical perspectives in cognitive neuroscience and introduces two implicit metrics through which personal agency can be empirically investigated. We report two experiments applying these methods to HCI problems. One shows that a new input modality - skin-based interaction - can substantially increase users' sense of agency. The second demonstrates that assistance techniques such as predictive mouse acceleration are able to preserve users' sense of agency, up to a threshold that can be determined experimentally. The methods presented provide designers with new ways of evaluating and refining interfaces and interaction techniques that users find empowering.

Title: Reactive Information Foraging: From Theory to Tools
Author list: David Piorkowski, Scott Fleming, Christopher Scaffidi, Christopher Bogart, Margaret Burnett, Bonnie John, Rachel Bellamy, Calvin Swart
Keywords: Software architecture and engineering; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: Information Foraging Theory (IFT) has revolutionized our understanding of how people seek information, but past studies of the theory have focused on users with static, unchanging goals. More recently, Reactive Information Foraging Theory has extended IFT to capture people’s evolving goals as they work on ill-structured problems. In this paper, we investigate how to use Reactive IFT for designing tools that aid information seekers by recommending useful sources of information. We designed and implemented four recommendation algorithms and empirically evaluated their ability to recommend useful code to professional software developers working on debugging tasks. We found that participants used recommendations to navigate efficiently among sources of information as well as to discover new information. The study also yielded advice regarding which algorithms provided the most useful recommendations, as well as when and why participants found recommendations useful (or not).

Title: MUSTARD: A Multi User See Through AR Display
Author list: Abhijit Karnik, Walterio Mayol-Cuevas, Sriram Subramanian
Keywords: Augmented Reality
Abstract: We present MUSTARD, a multi-user dynamic random hole see-through display, capable of delivering viewer dependent information for objects behind a glass cabinet. Multiple viewers are allowed to observe both the physical object(s) being augmented and their location dependent annotations at the same time. The system consists of two liquid-crystal (LC) panels within which physical objects can be placed. The back LC panel serves as a dynamic mask while the front panels serves as the data. We first describe the basic principle of MUSTARD and then examine various functions that can be used to minimize crosstalk between multiple viewer positions. We compare different conflict management strategies using PSNR and the quality mean opinion score of HDR-VDP2. Finally, through a user-study we show that users can clearly identify images and objects even when the images shown have strong conflicting regions; demonstrating that our system works even in the most extreme of circumstances.

Title: How Do We Find Personal Files?: The Effect of OS, Presentation & Depth on File Navigation
Author list: Ofer Bergman, Steve Whittaker, Mark Sanderson, Rafi Nachmias, Anand Ramamoorthy
Keywords: Usability Research; Information Architecture; Visualization; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: Folder navigation is the main way that computer users retrieve their own personal files. However we know surprisingly little about navigation, particularly about how it is affected by the operating system used, interface presentation and folder structure. To investigate this, we asked 289 participants in a naturalistic setting to retrieve 1,109 of their active files. We analyzed the 4,948 resulting retrieval steps, i.e. moves through the hierarchical folder tree. Results show: (a) significant differences in overall retrieval time between PC and Mac that arise from different organizational strategies rather than interface design; (b) Windows default presentation is suboptimal - if replaced, retrieval time could be reduced substantially and (c) contrary to our expectation, folder depth did not affect step duration. We discuss possible reasons for these results and suggest directions for future research.

Title: Exploring User Motivations for Eyes-free Interaction on Mobile Devices
Author list: Bo Yi, Xiang Cao, Morten Fjeld, Shengdong Zhao
Keywords: Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Interaction Design; User Interface Design
Abstract: While there is increasing interest in creating eyes-free interaction technologies and techniques, a solid analysis of why users need or desire eyes-free interaction has yet to be presented. To gain a better understanding of such user motivations we conducted an exploratory study with four focus groups. Based on the outcome of this study, we suggest a categorization of motivations for eyes-free interaction on mobile devices. The categories are: environmental, social, device features, and personal. Exploring and analyzing these categories, we present early insights pointing to design implications for future eyes-free interactions.

Title: An Evaluation of How Small User Interface Changes Can Improve Scientists’ Analytic Strategies
Author list: Radu Jianu, David Laidlaw
Keywords: Process Improvement; Visualization; User Studies; User Interface Design
Abstract: Subtle changes in analysis system interfaces can be used \ purposely to alter users’ analytic behaviors. In a controlled \ study subjects completed three analyses at one-week intervals \ using an analysis support system. Control subjects used \ one interface in all sessions. Test subjects used modified \ versions in the last two sessions: a first set of changes aimed \ at increasing subjects’ use of the system and their consideration \ of alternative hypotheses; a second set of changes aimed \ at increasing the amount of evidence collected. Results show \ that in the second session test subjects used the interface \ 39%more and switched between hypotheses 19%more than \ in the first session. They then collected 26% more evidence \ in the third than in the second session. These increases differ \ significantly (p< 0.05) from near constant control rates. We \ hypothesize that this approach can be used in many real applications \ to guide analysts unobtrusively towards improved \ analytic strategies.

Title: Diversity among Enterprise Online Communities: Collaborating, Teaming, and Innovating through Social Media
Author list: Michael Muller, Kate Ehrlich, Inbal Ronen, Adam Perer, Ido Guy, Tara Matthews
Keywords: Virtual Community / Community Computing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Social Computing and Social Navigation; Office and Workplace; User Studies
Abstract: There is a growing body of research into the adoption and use of social software in an enterprise, including blogs wikis, shared bookmarks, shared files and social networking sites. However, less is known about how groups such as communities might use this technology.  How do groups appropriate the technologies? What organizational structures emerge? We examined a production environment for online communities in the enterprise. In a study with nearly 200 very active online enterprise communities, we found similarities as well as differences between conventional online communities and new structures and use patterns that have arisen within the communities space, including Communities of Practice, large-scale Teams, Technical support groups, Idea Labs, and Recreation groups. These entities in the communities application differed from each other in size, creation of shared resources, and relationship-building. We discuss the implications of these results for design of community support features, services for people seeking communities, and organizations looking to derive specific value from their online groups.

Title: EEG Analysis of Implicit Human Visual Perception
Author list: Maryam Mustafa, Lea Lindemann, Marcus Magnor
Keywords: User and Cognitive models; Video Content / Communications; Visualization; Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling)
Abstract: Image Based Rendering (IBR) allows interactive scene exploration from images alone. However, despite considerable development in the area, one of the main obstacles to better quality and more realistic visualizations is the occurrence of visually disagreeable artifacts. In this paper we present a methodology to map out the perception of IBR-typical artifacts. This work presents an alternative to traditional image and video quality evaluation methods by using an EEG device to determine the implicit visual processes in the human brain. Our work demonstrates the distinct differences in the perception of different types of visual artifacts and the implications of these differences.

Title: The normal natural troubles of driving with GPS
Author list: Barry Brown, Eric Laurier
Keywords: Video Analysis; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Transport
Abstract: In-car GPS based satellite navigation systems are now a common part of driving, providing turn-by-turn navigation instructions on smartphones, portable units or in-car dashboard navigation systems. This paper uses interactional analysis of video data from fifteen naturalistically recorded journeys with GPS to understand the navigational practices deployed by drivers and passengers. The paper documents five types of ‘trouble’ where GPS systems cause issues and confusion for drivers around: destinations, routes, maps & sensors, timing  and relevance and legality. The paper argues that to design GPS systems better we need to move beyond the notion of a docile driver who follows GPS command blindly, to a better understanding of how drivers, passengers and GPS systems work together. We develop this in discussing how technology might better support ‘instructed action’.

Title: Understanding heart rate sharing: Towards unpacking physiosocial space
Author list: Petr Slovák, Joris Janssen, Geraldine Fitzpatrick
Keywords: Computer-Mediated Communication; Home; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User Studies
Abstract: Advances in biosensing make it possible to include heart rate monitoring in \ applications and several studies have suggested that heart rate communication \ has potential for improving social connectedness. However, it is not known how \ people understand heart rate feedback, or what issues need to be taken into \ account when designing technologies including heart rate feedback. To \ explore this, we created a heart rate communication probe that was used in two \ qualitative in-lab studies and a two-week field trial in participants' homes. \ Results show that heart rate feedback is a strong connectedness cue that affects \ the interaction in various ways, depending on a number of interrelated factors. \ In particular, we found two distinct categories of effects: heart rate as \ information and  heart rate as connection. We propose two mechanisms that could \ explain these observations and draw out the implications they have for future \ use of heartbeat communication to support social connectedness or other aspects \ of social interaction.

Title: NetCharts: Supporting Analytic Provenance when Exploring Large Multivariate, Heterogeneous Networks
Author list: Cody Dunne, Nathalie Henry Riche, Bongshin Lee, Ronald Metoyer, George Robertson
Keywords: Visualization; Visual System Design / Visual Design; User Interface Design
Abstract: Exploring large network datasets, such as scientific collaboration networks, is challenging because they often contain a large number of nodes/edges, multiple types of nodes/edges, and multiple attributes for nodes/edges. Analyses of such networks are often long and complex, and may require several sessions by multiple users. Therefore, it is often difficult for users to recall their own exploration history or share it with others. We introduce NetCharts, an interactive visualization that leverages exploration history and the aggregation capabilities of familiar charts such as bar charts and tag clouds. To facilitate large network analysis, it integrates aggregation with network exploration, supports a novel pivoting mechanism for transitioning between aggregates, and provides a new hybrid chart that combines a bar chart with an arc diagram. Through a qualitative study with ten users and a three month long field study with a team of archeologists, we demonstrate the effectiveness of NetCharts in supporting analytic provenance including analysis comprehension, data insight, and exploration recall.

Title: DisplayStacks: Interaction Techniques for Stacks of Flexible Thin-Film Displays
Author list: Audrey Girouard, Aneesh Tarun, Roel Vertegaal
Keywords: Prototyping; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies
Abstract: Stacking physical documents is one of the main forms of spatio-temporal organization of information. In this paper we present DisplayStacks, a system that enables physical stacking of digital documents via piles of flexible E Ink displays. With a conductive dot pattern sensor attached to the flexible display, we dynamically track the position and orientation of these displays in relation to one another. We introduce mechanisms for interacting with these physical stacks for access and manipulation of information using asymmetric bimanual interactions, such as providing contextual overviews. We make use of flexible E Ink displays augmented with sensors to enable dy¬namic manipulation of information in stacked displays.

Title: Fighting for My Space: Coping Mechanisms for SNS Boundary Regulation
Author list: Pamela Wisniewski, Heather Lipford, David Wilson
Keywords: Privacy; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Virtual Community / Community Computing; World Wide Web and Hypermedia; Office and Workplace; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Interaction Design; User and Cognitive models
Abstract: Sharing information online via social network sites (SNSs) is at an all-time high, yet research shows that users often exhibit a marked dissatisfaction in using such sites. A compelling explanation for this dichotomy is that users are struggling against their SNS environment in an effort to achieve their preferred levels of privacy for regulating social interactions. Our research investigates users’ SNS boundary regulation behavior. This paper presents results from a qualitative interview-based study to identify “coping mechanisms” that users devise outside the SNS user interface in order to manage interpersonal boundaries. Our categorization of such mechanisms provides insight into interaction design issues and opportunities for new SNSs features.

Title: "Then Click 'OK!'" Extracting References to Interface Elements in Online Documentation
Author list: Adam Fourney, Michael Terry
Keywords: Database access / Information Retrieval; World Wide Web and Hypermedia
Abstract: The Internet contains a large volume of reference material related to the use of interactive systems. Past work has demonstrated the value of deriving structured information from this natural language technical documentation, but has not adequately solved the problem of identifying the commands, menu items, and other widgets referenced therein. In this paper, we describe why this is a challenging problem, and discuss how certain informal conventions in tutorial writing can be leveraged to better detect widgets referenced in this context. We then introduce a set of features which reflect these conventions, and present a classifier that is able to recognize widget references with an average accuracy of 93.7%.

Title: Looking At You: Fused Gyro and Face Tracking for Viewing Large Imagery on Mobile Devices
Author list: Neel Joshi, Abhishek Kar, Michael Cohen
Keywords: Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Input and Interaction Technologies
Abstract: We present a touch-free interface for viewing large imagery on mobile devices. In particular, we focus on viewing paradigms for 360 degree panoramas, parallax image sequences, and long multi-perspective panoramas. We describe a sensor fusion methodology that combines face tracking using a front facing camera with gyroscope data to produce a robust signal that defines the viewer's 3D position relative to the display. The gyroscopic data provides both low latency feedback and allows extrapolation of the face position beyond the the field-of-view of the front facing camera. We also demonstrate a hybrid position and rate control that uses the viewer's 3D position to drive exploration of very large image spaces. We report on the efficacy of the hybrid control vs. position only control through a user study.

Title: Taming Wild Behavior: The Input Observer for Obtaining Lab-Quality Text Entry and Mouse Pointing Measures from Naturalistic Everyday Computer Use
Author list: Abigail Evans, Jacob Wobbrock
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Performance Metrics
Abstract: We present the Input Observer, a tool that can run quietly in the background of users’ computers and measure their text entry and mouse pointing performance from naturalistic everyday use. In lab studies, participants are presented with prescribed tasks, enabling easy identification of speeds and errors. In naturalistic use, no such prescriptions exist. We therefore devised novel algorithms to segment text entry and mouse pointing input streams into “trials.” We are also the first to measure errors for unprescribed text entry and mouse pointing. To measure errors, we utilize web search engines, adaptive offline dictionaries, an Automation API, and crowdsourcing. Capturing errors allows us to employ Crossman’s (1957) correction for normalizing speed-accuracy tradeoffs when calculating Fitts’ law throughputs. To validate the Input Observer, we compared its measures from 12 participants over a week of computer use to the same participants’ results from a lab study. Overall, in the lab and field, average text entry speeds were 74.47 WPM and 80.59 WPM, respectively. Average uncorrected error rates were near zero, at 0.12% and 0.28%. For mouse pointing, average movement times were 971 ms and 870 ms. Average pointing error rates were 4.42% and 4.66%. Average throughputs were 3.48 bits/s and 3.45 bits/s. Device makers, researchers, and assistive technology specialists may benefit from measures of “wild behavior.”

Title: AccessRank: Predicting What Users Will Do Next
Author list: Stephen Fitchett, Andy Cockburn
Keywords: Software Engineering Methods and Processes - Mathematical/Formal; Database access / Information Retrieval; Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); Performance Metrics
Abstract: We introduce AccessRank, an algorithm that predicts revisitations and reuse in a variety of contexts such as file accesses, website visits, window switches, and command lines. AccessRank uses many sources of input to generate its predictions, including recency, frequency, temporal clustering, and time of day. Simulations based on log records of real user interaction across a diverse range of applications show that AccessRank more accurately predicts upcoming accesses than other algorithms. The prediction lists generated by AccessRank are also shown to be more stable than other algorithms that have good predictive capability, which can be important for usability when items are presented in lists as users can rely on their spatial memory for target location. Finally, we present examples of how real world applications might use AccessRank.

Title: WalkType: Using Accelerometer Data to Accomodate Situational Impairments in Mobile Touch Screen Text Entry
Author list: Mayank Goel, Leah Findlater, Jacob Wobbrock
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; User Studies
Abstract: The lack of tactile feedback makes typing on touch screen devices difficult, a challenge exacerbated when situational impairments like vibration and divided attention arise in mobile settings. We introduce WalkType, an adaptive text entry system that leverages the mobile device’s built-in tri-axis accelerometer to compensate for extraneous movement while walking. WalkType’s classification model uses multiple sources of information, including the displacement and acceleration of the device, and inference about the user’s footsteps. Additionally, WalkType models finger touch location and finger distance traveled on the screen, features that increase overall accuracy regardless of movement. The final model was built on typing data collected from 16 participants. In a controlled study comparing WalkType to a control condition, WalkType reduced uncorrected errors by 45.2% and increased typing speed by 12.9% while participants were walking.

Title: A Quantitative Explanation of Governance in a Peer-Production Online Community
Author list: Chandan Sarkar, Donghee Wohn, Cliff Lampe, Kurt DeMaagd
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; User Studies
Abstract: In this paper, we examine how users’ evaluations of content produced for an online community is taken into consideration by administrators when they decide to delete content. Incorporating about 10 years of server data from the online peer-production community Everything2, we looked at how specific features of voting predicted deletion of posts. We found that not all types of voting are the same: negative voting of users was the strongest factor explaining deletion of a write-up. Receiving a positive vote from a higher social status member decreases the chances of deletion, while receiving a positive vote from a normal user has a very little effect on the deletion of content.

Title: Understanding the Language and Structure of  End-User Descriptions of Data Visualizations
Author list: Ronald Metoyer, Bongshin Lee, Nathalie Henry Riche, Mary Czerwinski
Keywords: Visualization; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; End-user Programming; Input and Interaction Technologies; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
Abstract: Tools exist for people to create visualizations with their data; however, they are often designed for programmers or they restrict less technical people to pre-defined templates. This can make creating novel, custom visualizations difficult for the average person. For example, existing tools typically do not support syntax or interaction techniques that are natural to end-users. To explore how to support a more natural production of data visualizations by end-users, we conducted an exploratory study to illuminate the structure and content of the language employed by end-users when describing data visualizations. We present our findings from the study and discuss their design implications for future visualization languages and toolkits.

Title: Codelets: Linking Interactive Documentation and Example Code in the Editor
Author list: Stephen Oney, Joel Brandt
Keywords: Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments
Abstract: Programmers frequently use instructive code examples found on the Web to overcome cognitive barriers while programming. These examples couple the concrete functionality present in the code with rich contextual information about how the code works. However, using these examples necessitates understanding, configuring, and integrating the code, all of which typically take place after the example enters the user’s code and has been removed from its original instructive context. In short, a user's interaction with an example continues well after the code is pasted. This paper investigates whether treating examples as “first-class” objects in the code editor — rather than simply as strings of text — will allow programmers to use examples more effectively. We explore this through the creation and evaluation of Codelets. A Codelet lives inside the user's code, and consists of a block of example code and an interactive helper widget that assists the user in understanding and integrating the ex-ample. The Codelet persists throughout the example’s lifecycle, remaining accessible even after configuration and integration is done. A comparative laboratory study with 20 participants found that programmers were able to complete tasks involving examples an average of 43% faster when us-ing Codelets than when using a standard Web browser.

Title: Implicit Imitation in Social Tagging: Semantic Reconstruction and Familiarity
Author list: Paul Seitlinger, Tobias Ley
Keywords: User and Cognitive models; Social Computing and Social Navigation; World Wide Web and Hypermedia; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: Social Tagging is a recent widespread phenomenon on the Web where people assign keywords (tags) to Web resources. It has been hypothesized to support collaborative sensemaking. In this paper, we examine some of the basic cognitive assumptions of this sensemaking process. In particular, we are presenting a multinomial model that is applied to the generation of tags. In line with the semantic imitation model of Fu and colleagues, we hypothesize that implicit processing can be understood as a semantic reconstruction of gist. The model contrasts this process with a recall of tags from an explicit verbatim memory trace. We tested this model in an experimental study in which after the search task students had to generate tags themselves. We exposed their answers to a multinomial model derived from the Fuzzy Trace Theory in order to obtain independent parameter estimates for the processes of explicit recall, semantic gist reconstruction and familiarity-based recall. As it turns out, a model that assumes all processes are at play explains the data well. Similar to results of our previous study, we find an influence of search intentions on the two processes. Our results have implications for interface and interaction design of social tagging systems, as well as for tag recommendation in these environments.

Title: An Exploratory Study of Eye Typing Fundamentals: Dwell Time, Text Entry Rate, Errors, and Workload
Author list: Kari-Jouko Räihä, Saila Ovaska
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; Universal (or Disability)  Access; Analysis Methods (e.g. Task/Interaction Modeling); Performance Metrics
Abstract: Although eye typing (writing on an on-screen keyboard with one’s eyes that are tracked by an eye tracker) has been studied for more than three decades, we still know relatively little about it from the users’ point of view. Standard measures like words per minute and keystrokes per character give only information about the effectiveness of the technology and the interaction techniques developed for eye typing. We conducted an extensive study with almost 5 hours of eye typing per participant, and report an extended qualitative and quantitative analysis of the relationship of dwell time, text entry rate, errors made, and workload experienced by the participants. The analysis method is comprehensive and stresses the need to consider different metrics in unison. The results highlight the importance of catering for individual differences and lead to suggestions for improvements in the interface.

Title: Rethinking Statistical Analysis Methods for CHI
Author list: Maurits Kaptein, Judy Robertson
Keywords: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Studies
Abstract: CHI researchers typically use a significance testing approach to statistical analysis when testing hypotheses during usability evaluations. However, the appropriateness of this approach is under increasing criticism, with statisticians, economists, and psychologists arguing against the use of routine interpretation of results using “canned” p values. Three problems with current practice - the fallacy of the transposed conditional, a neglect of power, and the reluctance to interpret the size of effects - can lead us to build weak theories based on vaguely specified hypothesis, resulting in empirical studies which produce results that are of limited practical or scientific use. Using the CHI debate on low vs. high fidelity prototyping as an example we address each of the three concerns and promote consideration of the magnitude and actual importance of effects, as opposed to statistical significance, as the new criteria for evaluating CHI research.

Title: Understanding Flicking on Curved Surfaces
Author list: Simon Voelker, Christine Sutter, Lei Wang, Jan Borchers
Keywords: Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User and Cognitive models; Usability Research
Abstract: Flicking is a common interaction technique to move objects across large interactive surfaces, but little is known about its suitability for use on non-planar, curved surfaces. Flicking consists of two stages: First, visually determining the direc- tion in which to flick the object, then planning and executing the corresponding gesture. Errors in both stages could influ- ence flicking accuracy. We investigated flicking interactions on curved interactive surface to evaluate which type of er- ror influences accuracy. Therefore, we carried out three user studies to analyze how each stage of flicking on a curved sur- face is influenced. Our main findings are: 1) Flicking gestures are more accurate if horizontal and vertical surface are joined by a continuous curve than if they are separated by an edge or gap. 2) Flicking gestures on curved surfaces are mostly influ- enced by the motor execution stage of the gesture rather than the visual perception stage. 3) Flicking accuracy decreases as the starting point of the gesture is moved closer to the curve. 4) We conclude with a first mathematical model to estimate the error users will make when flicking across a curve.

Title: Analysis in Practical Usability Evaluation: A Survey Study
Author list: Asbjørn Følstad, Effie Law, Kasper Hornbæk
Keywords: Usability Testing and Evaluation; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Analysis is a key part of conducting usability evaluations, yet rarely systematically studied. Thus, we lack direction on how to do research on supporting practitioners’ analysis and loose an opportunity for practitioners to learn from each other. We have surveyed 155 usability practitioners on the analysis in their latest usability evaluation. Analysis is typically flexible and light-weight. At the same time, practitioners see a need to strengthen reliability in evaluation. The identification of usability problems depends equally on findings related to users’ experience and findings related to task performance. Redesign is closely integrated with analysis; more than half of the respondents provide visual redesign suggestions in their evaluation deliverables. We provide six recommendations for future research to better support analysis.

Title: Drawing the city: Differing perceptions of the urban environment
Author list: Frank Bentley, Henriette Cramer, William Hamilton, Santosh Basapur
Keywords: User Studies; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Multidisciplinary Design / Interdisciplinary Design
Abstract: In building location-based services, it is important to present information in ways that correspond to how individuals view and navigate the city. We conducted an adaptation of the 1970s Mental Maps study by Stanley Milgram in order to better understand differences in people’s views of the city based on their backgrounds and technology use. We correlated data from a demographic questionnaire with the map data from our participants to perform a first-of-its-kind statistical analysis on differences in hand-drawn city maps. We describe our study, findings, and design implications for location-based services.

Title: Supporting the social context of technology appropriation: On a synthesis of sharing tools and tool knowledge
Author list: Sebastian Draxler, Gunnar Stevens, Martin Stein, Alexander Boden, David Randall
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Office and Workplace; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Prototyping
Abstract: There is an increasing spread of flexible software applications that can be modified by adding components (some-times called plug-ins or add-ons). A popular example in the software development domain is Eclipse, a flexible development environment that can be extended with literally thousands of different plug-ins. However, searching, in-stalling and configuring new plug-ins requires complex overhead work that is only weakly supported by existing support mechanisms. Recent research has highlighted the related practices of learning about new plug-ins and tailor-ing software tools as being highly cooperative, situated, socially embedded, and often connected to particular work situations. In this paper, we provide an ethnographic ac-count of appropriation practices in the context of Eclipse. Based on an empirical study in small software enterprises, we develop an understanding of appropriation as a social and collaborative activity. We then suggest design principles for appropriation support that are grounded in the practices we have found in the field, and present a prototypical implementation of the concept that extends existing mechanisms of sharing tools and tool-knowledge.

Title: Finding and Assessing Social Media Information Sources in the Context of Journalism
Author list: Nicholas Diakopoulos, Munmun De Choudhury, Mor Naaman
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Social media is already a fixture for reporting for many journalists, especially around breaking news events where non-professionals may already be on the scene to share an eyewitness report, photo, or video of the event. However, the huge amounts of content posted in conjunction with such events serve as a challenge to finding interesting and trustworthy sources in the din of the stream. In this paper we develop and investigate new methods for filtering and assessing the verity of sources found through social media, such as Twitter, by journalists. We take a human centered design approach to developing a system, SRSR (“Seriously Rapid Source Review”), informed by journalistic practices and knowledge of information production in events. We then used the system, together with a realistic reporting scenario, to evaluate the filtering and visual cue features that we developed. Our evaluation offers insights into social media information sourcing practices and challenges, and highlights the role technology can play in the solution.

Title: The Case of the Missed Icon: Change Blindness on Mobile Devices
Author list: Ashweeni Beeharee
Keywords: Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Visualization; User Interface Design
Abstract: Insights into human visual attention have benefited many areas of computing, but perhaps more significantly visualization and UI design. With the proliferation of mobile devices capable of supporting significantly complex applications on small screens, demands on mobile UI design and the user’s visual system are becoming greater. In this paper, we report results from an empirical study of human visual attention, specifically the Change Blindness phenomenon, on handheld mobile devices and its impact on mobile UI design. It is arguable that due to the small size of the screen - unlike a typical computer monitor - a greater visual coverage of the mobile device is possible, and that these phenomenons may occur less frequently during the use of the device, or even that they may not occur at all. Our study shows otherwise. \   \ We tested for Change Blindness (CB) and Inattentional Blindness (IB) in a single-modal, mobile context and attempted to establish factors in the application interface design that induce and/or reduce their occurrences. The results show that both CB and IB can and do occur while using mobile devices. The results also suggest that the number of separate attendable items on-screen is directly proportional to rates of CB. Newly inserted objects were correctly identified more often than changes applied to existing on-screen objects. These results suggest that it is important for mobile UI designers to take these aspects of visual attention into account when designing mobile applications that attempt to deliver visual changes or notifications to the users \

Title: Determining the Orientation of Proximate Mobile Devices using their Back Facing Camera
Author list: David Dearman, Richard Guy, Khai Truong
Keywords: Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments
Abstract: Providing proximate devices with each other’s orientation can support natural forms of interaction. In this paper, we present a method to determine the relative orientation of proximate mobile devices using the backside camera and we introduce a service (Orienteer) we developed to provide mobile devices with orientation-awareness. We conducted an informal exploration using pairs of participants that used two orientation-aware applications developed using Orienteer to share content with one another. We show that interactions using orientation are natural and compelling to application users, but developers need to consider how the orientation information can benefit their user and that they should apply orientation-aware interactions appropriately.

Title: Supporting the implicit acquisition of second language vocabulary using a live wallpaper
Author list: David Dearman, Khai Truong
Keywords: Context-Aware Computing; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments
Abstract: An essential aspect of learning a second language is the acquisition of vocabulary. However, acquiring vocabulary is often a protracted process that requires repeated and spaced exposure; which can be difficult to accommodate given the busyness of daily living. In this paper, we explore if a learner can implicitly acquire second language vocabulary through her explicit interactions with her mobile phone (e.g., navigating multiple home screens) using an interface we developed called Vocabulary Wallpaper. In addition, we examine if the type of vocabulary this technique exposes to the learner, whether it is contextually relevant or contextually-independent will influence the learner’s rate of vocabulary acquisition. The results of our study show participants were able to use Vocabulary Wallpaper to increase the number of second language vocabulary that they can recognize and recall and their rate of vocabulary acquisition was significantly greater when presented with a contextually relevant vocabulary than a contextually-independent vocabulary.

Title: Accurate Measurements of Motor Performance from Uncontrolled Experiments
Author list: Krzysztof Gajos, Katharina Reinecke
Keywords: Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Agents and Intelligent Systems; Universal (or Disability)  Access; User Studies
Abstract: Many experiments in HCI require accurate measurements of human motor performance on simple user interface tasks. To ensure reliable results, they usually have to rely on carefully designed procedures, controlled environmental conditions, and direct supervision of participants. Such experiments are time consuming and are often a factor limiting the pace of innovation. As an alternative to controlling study conditions, we propose to collect data from remote, unsupervised participants, and automatically filter it for reliable observations.
