We evaluated our SSM-based recolorer against two existing systems in a controlled study where we compared people’s color-matching performance under several environmental conditions. The study included participants with congenital CVD and those without CVD. Our results show that the SSM-based recolorer allowed significantly better accuracy and response time in color- matching tasks. This work demonstrates the value of a situation-specific approach to recoloring, and shows that this technique can substantially improve the usability of color displays for users of all types.

Title: An Automatically Generated Interlanguage Tailored to Speakers of Minority but Culturally Influenced Languages
Author list: Luis Leiva, Vicent Alabau
Keywords: Computer-Mediated Communication; Universal (or Disability)  Access; Internationalization / Localization
Abstract: Users of minority languages often cannot access to the vast amount of resources that are otherwise available in majority languages. To this concern, data-driven Machine Translation (MT) seems a useful asset. However, MT depends on parallel corpora, which is rather limited for such a minority languages. In this paper, we stress the fact that most languages share common roots, and so we can reuse this information to build a usable MT system. Our approach leverages a family of languages closely related to the speaker's native language to construct translations in a coherent mix of these languages. Experimental results indicate that translations generated by following our method can be easily understood, being also a useful aid for users who are not proficient in foreign languages. Our research highlights several key areas for further enhancing the human-computer communication.

Title: SphereAvatar: A Situated Display to Represent a Remote Collaborator
Author list: Oyewole Oyekoya, William Steptoe, Anthony Steed
Keywords: Augmented Reality and Tangible UI; Visualization; Augmented Reality; Virtual Reality
Abstract: An emerging form of telecollaboration utilizes physical representations of remote participants (visitors) in the local physical space (destination). An example is a telepresence robot where the robot captures the destination so that the remote visitors can see and hear what is going, but also acts as a proxy for the visitor. We propose the use of spherical displays to represent the visitors in the destination. We suggest that this has two advantages over other representations: it is possible to tell the identity of the visitor from any direction; and with suitable graphics, it is possible to tell where the visitor is looking. In an experiment we investigate the best ways in which to represent a visitor on a spherical display and we evaluate how accurately the representations convey the direction of an avatar’s head gaze.

Title: Best Faces Forward: A Large-scale Study of People Search in the Enterprise
Author list: Ido Guy, Sigalit Ur, Inbal Ronen, Sara Werber, Tolga Oral
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Office and Workplace; User Studies
Abstract: This paper presents Faces, an application built to enable effective people search in the enterprise. We take advantage of the popularity Faces has gained within a globally distributed enterprise to provide an extensive analysis of how and why people search is used within the organization. Our study is primarily based on an analysis of the Faces query log over a period of more than four months, with over a million queries and tens of thousands of users. The analysis results are presented across four dimensions: queries, users, clicks, and actions, and lay the foundation for further advancement and research on the topic.

Title: Choosing to Interleave: Human Error and Information Access Cost
Author list: Jonathan Back, Anna Cox, Duncan Brumby
Keywords: User and Cognitive models; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: People are prone to making more errors when multitasking. Thus in safety-critical environments, it is often considered safer to perform tasks sequentially. Here we explore how the cost of accessing information affects how people choose to interleave. An empirical study based on a medical scenario was conducted. Participants had to program infusion pump devices using information from a prescription form. The physical and mental effort involved in accessing information was manipulated. This was achieved by simply moving the prescription form. Once trained on how to program one device, participants were free to decide how they interleaved the programming of two devices. We demonstrate that by increasing the information access cost, individuals are less likely to omit a required task step. This is because they adopt a more memory-intensive strategy, which encourages interleaving at natural boundaries, i.e., after completing a subgoal. Interleaving at other points disrupts subgoal execution, which can result in task steps being forgotten.

Title: ReticularSpaces: Activity-Based Computing Support for Physically Distributed and Collaborative Smart Spaces
Author list: Jakob Bardram, Sofiane Gueddana, Steven Houben, Søren Nielson
Keywords: Multimedia UIs; Computer-Mediated Communication; Context-Aware Computing; Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Information Architecture; Video Content / Communications; User Studies
Abstract: Smart space technology has focused on supporting multiple displays and devices for co-located participants. But users are left to cope with heterogeneous interfaces and information organization as few approaches include collaboration with mobile and remote users outside the smart space. In this paper, we present ReticularSpaces, a multi-display smart space system that addresses these challenges by (a) supporting a unified interaction with applications and documents through ReticUI, a novel UI for distributed displays; (b) managing the complex flow of tasks between users and displays; (c) extending smart room interaction to mobile users in a local, remote or ‘nomadic’ settings; and (d) supporting for collaboration among local and remote users. We describe the motivation, design, and architecture of the system, and report from a preliminary feasibility study. The study shows that participants found ReticularSpaces useful and effective and point out to new open issues in interactive distributed systems for smart environment.

Title: Impression Formation in Corporate People Tagging
Author list: Daphne Raban, Avinoam Danan, Inbal Ronen, Ido Guy
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication
Abstract: This research explores the relationship between self-presentation and perception by others as manifested explicitly through the use of tags in a people tagging system.   The study provides insights relevant for the professional/work context since it is based on a system implemented within a large global enterprise.  We developed a detailed codebook and used it to categorize 9,506 tags assigned to a sample of the system users. Our analysis examines the use of self tags versus social tags (assigned by others) across different categories and sub-categories. We particularly analyze the degree of overlap between both types of tags in order to inspect the commonalities and differences between self presentation and perception by others and some of the popular terms used to describe participants.

Title: WebTicket: Account Management Using Printable Tokens
Author list: Eiji Hayashi, Bryan Pendleton, Fatih OZENC, Jason Hong
Keywords: Security
Abstract: Passwords are the most common authentication scheme today. However, it is difficult for people to memorize random sequences of characters, as encouraged by best practices. Additionally, passwords do not provide protection against phishing attacks. This paper, introduces WebTicket, a low cost, easy-to-use and reliable web account management system that uses "tickets", which are tokens that contain a two-dimensional barcode that can be printed or stored on smartphones. Users can log into accounts by presenting the barcodes to webcams connected to computers. Through two lab studies and one field study consisting of 59 participants in total, we found that WebTicket can provide reliable authentication and phishing resilience.

Title: Ultra-Tangibles: Creating Movable Tangible Objects on Interactive Tables
Author list: Mark Marshall, Thomas Carter, Jason Alexander, Sriram Subramanian
Keywords: Tangible UIs
Abstract: Tangible User Interfaces placed on interactive surfaces allow users to employ a physical object to manipulate digital content. However, creating the reverse effect—having digital content manipulate a tangible object placed on the surface—is a more challenging task. We present a new approach to this problem, using ultrasound-based air pressure waves to move multiple tangible objects, independently, around an interactive surface. We describe the technical background, design, implementation, and test cases for such a system. We conclude by discussing practical uses of our system, Ultra-Tangibles, in the creation of new tangible user interfaces.

Title: Phylo-Genie:  Engaging Students in Collaborative 'Tree-Thinking' through Tabletop Techniques
Author list: Bertrand Schneider, Megan Strait, Laurence Muller, Sarah Elfenbein, Orit Shaer, Chia Shen
Keywords: E-Learning and Education
Abstract: Phylogenetic trees are representations of evolutionary relationships amongst species.  Interviews of instructors and students have revealed that novice biologists have great difficulty understanding phylogenetics. Moreover, misinterpretations of phylogenetics are common among college-level students. In this paper we present Phylo-Genie, a tabletop interface for fostering collaborative learning of phylogenetics.  We conducted an experimental study with 56 participants, comparing students’ conceptual learning and engagement using Phylo-Genie as: 1) a multi-touch tabletop interface and 2) a pen and paper activity. Our findings show that the tabletop implementation fosters collaborative learning by engaging users in the activity. We also shed light on the way in which our design principles facilitated collaboration in a tabletop environment.

Title: Omnipedia: Bridging the Wikipedia Language Gap
Author list: Patti Bao, Brent Hecht, Samuel Carton, Mahmood Quaderi, Michael Horn, Darren Gergle
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Social Computing and Social Navigation
Abstract: We present Omnipedia, a system that allows Wikipedia readers to gain insight from up to 25 language editions of Wikipedia simultaneously. Omnipedia highlights the similarities and differences that exist among Wikipedia language editions, and allows users to view information that is unique to each language as well as that which is shared more widely. We detail solutions to numerous front-end and algorithmic challenges inherent to providing users with a hyperlingual Wikipedia experience. These include visualizing Wikipedia content in a language-neutral way and aligning data in the face of diverse information organization strategies and language structures. We then present a user study of Omnipedia to characterize how people interact with information using a highly multilingual lens. We found that users actively sought out information exclusive to unfamiliar language editions and strategically compared how language editions defined concepts. Finally, we briefly discuss how the Omnipedia system generalizes to other sites with similar language barriers.

Title: Biometric-Rich Gestures: A Novel Approach to Authentication on Multi-touch Devices
Author list: Napa Sae-Bae, Nasir Memon, Katherine Isbister
Keywords: Security; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing
Abstract: More and more computing devices come equipped with multi-touch capabilities. Some, such as smart phones and tablets, may not have a keyboard at all. However, most multi-touch devices still use typed text passwords for authentication. Typing on a glass screen, often on a smaller surface area, leads users to select weak, short passwords. It is a well known problem in authentication that users are rarely able to stick to recommendations for creating strong passwords. We propose taking advantage of the multi-touch surface to combine biometric techniques with gestural input. We defined a comprehensive set of five-finger touch gestures, based upon classifying movement characteristics of the center of the palm and fingertips, and tested them all in a user study that combined biometric data collection with usability questions. Using pattern recognition techniques, we built a classifier to recognize the unique biometric gesture characteristics of an individual user. We achieved a 90% accuracy rate when using single gestures, and saw a significant improvement when multiple gestures were performed in sequence. We found that user ratings of a gesture’s desirable characteristics (ease, pleasure, excitement) correlated with a gesture’s actual biometric recognition rate--that is to say, user ratings aligned well with gestural security, in contrast to typical text-based passwords. Based on these results, we conclude that multi-touch gestures show great promise as an authentication mechanism.

Title: Tag, You Can See It! Using Tags for Access Control in Photo Sharing
Author list: Peter Klemperer, Yuan Liang, Michelle Mazurek, Manya Sleeper, Blase Ur, Lujo Bauer, Lorrie Faith Cranor, Nitin Gupta, Michael Reiter
Keywords: Security; User Studies; Usability Research; Privacy
Abstract: Users have rich and often complex photo sharing preferences, but properly configuring access control can be difficult and time-consuming. In an 18-participant laboratory study, we explore whether the keywords and captions with which users tag their photos can be used to help users create and maintain access-control policies more intuitively. We find that (a) tags created for organizational purposes can be repurposed to create efficient and reasonably accurate access-control rules; (b) users tagging with access control in mind develop coherent strategies that lead to significantly more accurate rules than those associated with organizational tags alone; and (c) participants understood and actively engaged with the concept of tag-based access control.

Title: Social Desirability Bias and Self-Reports of Motivation: A Cross-Cultural Study of Amazon Mechanical Turk in the US and India
Author list: Judd Antin, Aaron Shaw
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Computer-Mediated Communication
Abstract: In this study we build on existing research about motivations \ to participate in online collaborative systems. We examine \ two specific challenges to many existing studies: (1) most \ studies of motivation in online contexts are based on survey \ self-reports, which are susceptible to effects such as social \ desirability bias, and (2) the current body of research about \ online motivation largely fails to examine potential differences \ in motivation across cultures. In this study we investigate \ these two issues through a study of individuals in the \ US and India who do work on the “crowdsourcing” service \ Amazon Mechanical Turk (“MTurk”). Results from more \ than 2400 MTurk workers (“Turkers”) in the two countries \ reveal not only distinct profiles of motivation across cultures, \ but also different profiles of social desirability effects. \ Among US Turkers, due to social desirability bias we find a \ marked over-reporting of each of four motivating factors we \ examined. The over-reporting was particularly large in the \ case of money as a motivator. In contrast, among Turkers \ in India we find a more complex pattern of social desirability \ effects, with workers under-reporting “killing time” and \ “fun” as motivations, and drastically over-reporting “sense \ of purpose.” We conclude by discussing these results and \ proposing implications for future research and design.

Title: ReGroup: Interactive Machine Learning  in Social Network Access Control
Author list: Saleema Amershi, James Fogarty, Dan Weld
Keywords: Agents and Intelligent Systems; Social Computing and Social Navigation
Abstract: We present ReGroup, a novel end-user interactive machine learning system to help people create custom, on-demand groups in online social networks. As people add members to a group, ReGroup learns a probabilistic model of group membership and suggests additional members. ReGroup also integrates human knowledge of shared group member properties by suggesting group characteristics for filtering.  \  \ Applying end-user interactive machine learning to social access control highlights several challenges for the design of effective interaction with machine learning. We identify these challenges and discuss how we address them in our design of ReGroup. Our evaluation shows that the various strategies enabled by ReGroup help for different kinds of groups. Furthermore, people perceived our ReGroup interface to be easier and quicker overall, choosing it as their favorite. This is important, because facilitating on demand creation of contextualized groups may help encourage better privacy practices in social networks.  \

Title: Examining Technology that Supports Community Policing
Author list: Sheena Lewis, Dan A. Lewis
Keywords: Virtual Community / Community Computing; Computer-Mediated Communication; Ethnography
Abstract: This paper investigates how citizens use technology to support community policing efforts. To explore the types of conversations that are shared on the community web forum, we conducted an ethnographic study. We analyzed 865 forum posts from a community crime web forum from April 2004 to June 2011. Our findings indicate the residents use the forum to: 1) build relationships by strengthening social ties, 2) discuss ways to take collective action, 3) share information and advice, and 4) regulate the social norms of the neighborhood and the web forum. Results suggest that technologies intended for crime prevention should be designed to support communication and problem-solving discussions amongst residents, as opposed to simply providing information to citizens.

Title: Mouse tracking: Measuring and predicting users' experience of web-based content
Author list: Vidhya Navalpakkam, Elizabeth Churchill
Keywords: Usability Research; Input and Interaction Technologies; Visualization; World Wide Web and Hypermedia; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Studies; User Experience Design / Experience Design; User Interface Design
Abstract: Previous studies have used mouse tracking as a tool to measure usability of webpages, user attention and search relevance. In this paper, we go beyond measurement of user behavior to prediction of the resulting user experience from mouse patterns alone. Specifically, we identify mouse markers that can predict user frustration and reading struggles at 75% accuracy (15% better than chance). We believe that mouse-based prediction of user experience is an important advance, and could potentially offer a scalable way to infer user experience on the web. In addition, we demonstrate that mouse tracking could be used for applications such as evaluating ad layout and ad noticing. More generally, it could  be used to infer user attention in complex webpages containing images, text and varied content,  including how attention patterns  vary  with page layout and user distraction.

Title: The Social Labor of Service Mediation: A Study  of the Work Practices of Food Assistance Outreach
Author list: Lynn Dombrowski, Amy Voida, Gillian R. Hayes, Melissa Mazmanian
Keywords: Social and Legal issues; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
Abstract: In this paper, we present the results of a study of the work practices of food assistance outreach workers. We introduce the construct of service mediation, which includes the social labor and work involved in enabling access to and the use of a service for another person. By building upon current understanding of mediation within HCI, we further explore the different types of activities necessary to enable access and use of services for clients, including outreach, technological assistance, providing knowledge, and ongoing engagement. These activities bring to light the ways in which a service involves fostering a process, bridging relationships, and providing broader scaffolding. The results of our work highlight the necessary role service mediation plays in facilitating use of services and service technologies.

Title: Annotating BI Visualization Dashboards: Needs & Challenges
Author list: Micheline Elias, Anastasia Bezerianos
Keywords: Visualization; Office and Workplace; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Annotations have been identified as an important aid in  analysis record-keeping and recently data discovery. In this paper we discuss the use of annotations on visualization dashboards, with a special focus on business intelligence (BI) analysis. In-depth interviews with experts lead to new annotation needs for multi-chart visualization systems, on which we based the design of a dashboard prototype that supports data and context aware annotations. We focus particularly on novel annotation aspects, such as multi-target annotations, annotation transparency across charts and data dimension levels, as well as annotation properties such as lifetime and validity. Moreover, our prototype is built on a data layer shared among different data-sources and BI applications, allowing cross application annotations. We discuss challenges in supporting context aware annotations in dashboards and other visualizations, such as dealing with changing annotated data, and provide design solutions. Finally we report reactions and recommendations from a different set of expert users.

Title: Understanding Mobile Q&A Usage: An Exploratory Study
Author list: Uichin Lee, Hyanghong Kang, Eunhee YI, Mun Yi, Jussi Kantola
Keywords: Perceptual & Vision-based UIs; Database access / Information Retrieval; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Social Computing and Social Navigation; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Home; Office and Workplace; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User Studies; Service Design
Abstract: Recently questioning and answering (Q\\&A) communities that facilitate knowledge sharing among people were introduced to the mobile environments such as Naver Mobile Q\\&A and ChaCha. Mobile Q\\&A is very different from traditional Q\\&A sites in that questions/answers are short in length and are exchanged via mobile devices (e.g., SMS or mobile Internet). While traditional Q\\&A sites have been well investigated, so far little is known about the mobile Q\\&A usage. To understand mobile Q\\&A usage, we analyzed 2.4 million question/answer pairs spanning over a 14 month period from Naver Mobile Q\\&A and performed a complementary survey study of 230 active mobile Q\\&A users. We find that mobile Q\\&A is deeply wired into users’ everyday life activities---its usage is largely dependent on users’ spatial, temporal, social contexts---and the key factors of mobile Q\\&A usage are accessibility/convenience of mobile Q\\&A, promptness of receiving answers, and users’ satisficing behavior of information seeking. We also observe that users tend to seek more factual information attributed to everyday life activities than traditional Q\\&A sites and exhibit a unique pattern of interactive behavior such as repeating and refining questions as coping strategies of seeking information needs. Our main findings reported in the paper have significant implications on the design of mobile Q\\&A systems.

Title: Evaluating the Effects of Latency in Online Video Scrubbing
Author list: Justin Matejka, Tovi Grossman, George Fitzmaurice
Keywords: Video Content / Communications; World Wide Web and Hypermedia
Abstract: We first conduct a study using abstracted video content to measure the effects of latency on video scrubbing performance and find that even very small amounts of latency can significantly degrade navigation performance. Based on these results, we present Swift, a technique that supports real-time scrubbing of online videos by overlaying a small, low resolution copy of the video during video scrubbing, and snapping back to the high resolution video when the scrubbing is completed or paused. A second study compares the Swift technique to traditional online video players on a collection of realistic live motion videos and content-specific search tasks which finds the Swift technique reducing completion times by as much as 72% even with a relatively low latency of 500ms. Lastly, we demonstrate that the Swift technique can be easily implemented using modern HTML5 web standards.

Title: Beyond Stereo: An Exploration of Unconventional Binocular Presentation for Novel Visual Experience
Author list: Haimo Zhang, Xiang Cao, Shengdong Zhao
Keywords: Perceptual & Vision-based UIs; Visualization
Abstract: Human stereo vision processes the two different images seen by the two eyes to generate depth sensation. While stereoscopic display technologies look at how to faithfully simulate the stereo viewing experience, we took a look out of this scope, to explore how we may present binocular image pairs that differ in other ways to create novel visual experience. This paper presents several interesting techniques we explored, and discusses their potential applications according to an informal user study.

Title: See Me, See You: A Lightweight Method for  Discriminating User Touches on Tabletop Displays
Author list: Hong Zhang, Xing-Dong Yang, Barrett Ens, Hai-Ning Liang, Pierre Boulanger, Pourang Irani
Keywords: Input and Interaction Technologies; User Studies; User Interface Design; Perceptual & Vision-based UIs
Abstract: Tabletop systems provide a versatile space for collaboration, yet, in many cases, are limited by the inability to differentiate the interactions of simultaneous users. We present See Me, See You, a lightweight approach for discriminating user touches on a vision-based tabletop. We contribute a valuable characterization of finger orientation distributions of tabletop users. We exploit this biometric trait with a machine learning approach to allow the system to predict the correct position of users as they touch the surface. We achieve accuracies as high as 98% in simple situations and above 92% in more challenging conditions, such as two-handed tasks. We show high acceptance from users, who can self-correct prediction errors without significant costs. See Me, See You is a viable solution for providing simple yet effective support for multi-user application features on tabletops.

Title: Breaking News on Twitter
Author list: Mengdie Hu, Shixia Liu, Furu Wei, Yingcai Wu, Kwan-Liu Ma
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: There has been a heated debate on whether Twitter would fundamentally change the way we produce, spread, and consume news after Osama Bin Laden's death leaked out through Twitter. To understand Twitter's role in the Osama Bin Laden story, we study how the news was broken and spread on Twitter. We confirm the claim that Twitter broke the news first, and find evidence that Twitter had convinced the majority of its audience by the time mainstream media announced the news. Studying the information flow on Twitter we found that the attention of general users was highly concentrated on a small number of "opinion leaders". Three groups of opinion leaders played key roles in spreading the news: individuals affiliated with media played a large part in breaking the news, mass media brought the news to a wider audience and provided eager Twitter users with content on external sites, and celebrities helped to spread the news and stimulate conversation. \

Title: Twitter and the Development of an Audience: Those Who Stay on Topic Thrive
Author list: Yi-Chia Wang, Robert Kraut
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative
Abstract: Although economists have long recognized the importance of a critical mass in growing a community, we know little about how it is achieved. This paper examines how initial topical focus influences communities’ ability to attract a critical mass. When starting an online community, organizers need to define its initial scope. Topically narrow communities will probably attract a homogeneous group of interested in its content and compatible with each other.  However, they are likely to attract fewer members than a diverse one because they offer only subset of the topics. This paper reports an empirical analysis of longitudinal data collected from Twitter, where each new Twitter poster is considered the seed of a potential online community. Users who focus the topics of their early tweets more narrowly ultimately attract more followers with more ties among them.  Our results shed light on the development of online social networking structures.

Title: Successful Classroom Deployment of a Social Document Annotation System
Author list: Sacha Zyto, David Karger, Mark Ackerman
Keywords: E-Learning and Education; Computer-Mediated Communication; Virtual Community / Community Computing; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
Abstract: NB is an in-place collaborative document annotation website targeting students reading lecture notes and draft textbooks.  Serving as a discussion forum in the document margins, NB lets users ask and answer questions about their reading material as they are reading. NB users can read and annotate documents using their web browsers, without any special plug-ins. We describe the NB system and its evaluation in real class environment, where students used it to submit their reading assignments, ask questions and get or provide feedback.  \  \ We focus on a particularly successful class deployment where the instructor adapted his teaching style to take students' comment into account.  We analyze the annotation practices that were observed---including the way geographic locality was exploited in ways unavailable in traditional forums---and discuss general design implications for online annotation tools in academia.

Title: What do users really care about? A comparison of usability problems found by users and experts on highly interactive websites
Author list: Helen Petrie, Christopher Power
Keywords: Usability Research; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; User Interface Design
Abstract: Expert evaluation methods, such as heuristic evaluation, are still popular in spite of numerous criticisms of their effectiveness.  This paper investigates the usability problems found in the evaluation of six highly interactive websites by 15 users and three different expert evaluation methods.  A grounded theory approach was taken to categorize 907 usability problems from the evaluation. Four major categories emerged: Physical presentation, Content, Information Architecture and Interactivity. Each major category had between 5 and 16 sub-categories. The categories and sub-categories were then analysed for whether they were found by users only, experts only or both users and experts.  This allowed us to develop an evidence-based set of 21 heuristics to assist in the development and evaluation of interactive websites.

Title: Group Hedonic Balance and Pair Programming Performance: Affective Interaction Dynamics as indicators of Performance
Author list: Malte Jung, Jan Chong, Larry Leifer
Keywords: Dialog Analysis; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Performance Metrics; Video Analysis
Abstract: Inspired by research on the role of affect in marital interactions, the authors examined whether affective interaction dynamics occurring within a 5-minute slice can predict pair programming performance. In a laboratory experiment with professional programmers, Group Hedonic Balance, a measure of the balance between positive and negative expressed affect, accounted for up to 35% of the variance in not only subjective but also objective pair programming performance. Implications include a new set of methods to study pair programming interactions and recommendations to improve pair programming performance.

Title: PixIO: Sharing Any Surface
Author list: Sasa Junuzovic, Kori Inkpen, Tom Blank, Anoop Gupta
Keywords: Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW); Computer-Mediated Communication; Children
Abstract: Task and reference spaces are important communication channels for remote collaboration. However, all existing systems for sharing these spaces have an inherent weakness: they cannot share arbitrary physical and digital objects on arbitrary surfaces. We present PixIO, a new cost-effective, light-weight device that solves this issue. It both shares physical and digital objects on arbitrary surfaces and provides rich referential awareness. To evaluate PixIO, we studied pairs of children playing remotely. They used PixIO to share the task-reference space and Skype Video to share the person space. The study results show that PixIO shared the play space in a natural and seamless way. We also found that children preferred having both spaces compared to having only one. Moreover, we found that removing the task-reference space caused stronger negative disruptions to the play task and engagement level than removing the person space. Similarly, we found that adding the task-reference space resulted in stronger positive disruptions.

Title: It’s Complicated: How Romantic Partners Use Facebook
Author list: Xuan Zhao, Victoria Schwanda, Dan Cosley
Keywords: Computer-Mediated Communication; Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Privacy
Abstract: Romantic partners face issues of relational development \ including managing information privacy, tension between \ individual and relational needs, and accountability to \ existing friends. Prior work suggests that affordances of \ social media might highlight and shape these tensions; to \ explore this, we asked 20 people to reflect daily for two \ weeks on feelings and decisions around their own and \ others’ Facebook use related to their relationship for two \ weeks. Most generally, we find that tensions arise when \ romantic partners must manage multiple relationships \ simultaneously because Facebook audiences are so present \ and so varied. People also engage in subtle negotiation \ around and appropriation of Facebook’s features to \ accomplish both personal and relational goals. By capturing \ both why people make these decisions and how Facebook’s \ affordances support them, we expect many of our insights \ to apply to studying other social media tools and designing \ new ones.

Title: Ripple effects of embedded social agents: Field study of a social robot in the workplace
Author list: Min Kyung Lee, Sara Kiesler, Jodi Forlizzi, Paul Rybski
Keywords: Robots; Empirical Methods, Qualitative
Abstract: Prior research has shown that context and social expectations affect people’s responses to interactive agents presented on computer screens or embodied in robots. Much of this research has been pursued in labs and brief field studies. Comparatively little is known about social agents embedded in the workplace, where employees have repeated interactions with the agent, alone and with others. We designed a social robot delivery service for a workplace, and evaluated this service over four months. We report on how employees responded to the robot and the service over repeated encounters. Despite employees’ knowledge of the robot as a machine, their encounters became surprisingly social, and social norms developed around treating the robot as workgroup member. Deliveries became workplace social events. We discuss the implications of these ripple effects for designing services incorporating social agents.

Title: Delta: A Tool For Representing and Comparing Workflows
Author list: Nicholas Kong, Tovi Grossman, Bjoern Hartmann, Maneesh Agrawala, George Fitzmaurice
Keywords: Creativity Support Tools; Visual Design; User Studies
Abstract: Tutorials and sample workflows for complicated, feature-rich software packages are widely available online. As a result users must differentiate and choose the most suitable workflow for their task. We present Delta, an interactive workflow visualization and comparison tool that helps users identify the tradeoffs between workflows. We conducted an initial study to identify the set of workflow attributes users consider when comparing workflows, finding that users consider result quality, their knowledge of commands, and the efficiency of the workflow. We then designed Delta to surface these attributes at three granularities: a high-level, clustered view; an intermediate-level list view that contains workflow summaries; and a low-level detail view that allows users to compare two individual workflows. Finally, we conducted an evaluation of Delta on a small corpus of 30 workflows and found that the intermediate list view provided the best information density. We conclude with thoughts on how such a workflow comparison system could be scaled up to larger corpora in the future.

Title: Why Johnny Can't Opt Out: A Usability Evaluation of Tools to Limit Online Behavioral Advertising
Author list: Pedro Leon, Blase Ur, Richard Shay, Yang Wang, Rebecca Balebako, Lorrie Cranor
Keywords: Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Studies; User Interface Design; Privacy
Abstract: We present results of a 45-participant laboratory study investigating the usability of tools to limit online behavioral advertising (OBA).  \ We tested nine tools, including tools that block access to advertising websites, tools that set cookies indicating a user's preference to opt out of OBA, and privacy tools that are built directly into web browsers. \ We interviewed participants about OBA, observed their behavior as they installed and used a privacy tool, and recorded their perceptions and attitudes about that tool. \ We found serious usability flaws in all nine tools we examined. \ The online opt-out tools were challenging for users to understand and configure. \  Users tend to be unfamiliar with most advertising companies, \ and therefore are unable to make meaningful choices. \ Users liked the fact that the browsers we tested had built-in Do-Not-Track features,  but were wary of whether advertising companies would respect this preference. Users struggled to install and configure blocking lists to make effective use of blocking tools. They often erroneously concluded the tool was blocking OBA when they had not properly configured it to do so. \

Title: Designing Social Translucence over Networks
Author list: Eric Gilbert
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Computer-Mediated Communication
Abstract: Social translucence is a landmark theory in social computing. Modeled on physical life, it guides designers toward elegant social technologies. However, we argue that it breaks down over modern social network sites because social networks resist its physical metaphors. Bridging this gap, we introduce a new theory called structural social translucence, relating triads to the design problems they cause. To explore the theory, we built a tool called notab.ly. Notab.ly addresses a triadic awareness problem by letting users know how many of their Twitter followers already a saw link via someone else they follow. During two months on the web, nearly 150K people used notab.ly a total of 1.3M times. Its widespread, viral use suggests that people want social translucence, but network structure gets in the way. We conclude the paper by illustrating applications of structural social translucence, arguing that new design problems lie at the intersection of social translucence and unexplored triads.

Title: Human Computation Tasks with Global Constraints: A Case Study
Author list: Haoqi Zhang, Edith Law, Rob Miller, Krzysztof Gajos, David Parkes, Eric Horvitz
Keywords: Social Computing and Social Navigation
Abstract: An important class of tasks that is underexplored in current human \ computation systems are complex tasks for which the solutions demand a \ set of global constraints to be met.  One example of such a task is \ itinerary planning, where solutions consist of a sequence of \ activities that meet the requirements specified by the \ requester. In this paper, we focus on the joint formulation of such \ plans as a case study of constraint-based human computation task and \ introduce a collaborative planning system called Mobi.  Mobi presents a \ single interface that enables participants to view the current solution context \ and make appropriate contributions based on current needs during \ the progression of collaboration.  We conduct experiments that \ show the end-to-end usability of Mobi, \ and that explain how the system enables a crowd to effectively and \ collaboratively resolve global constraints.

Title: Pay Attention! Designing Adaptive Agents that Monitor and Improve User Engagement
Author list: Daniel Szafir, Bilge Mutlu
Keywords: Agents and Intelligent Systems; E-Learning and Education; User Studies; Robots
Abstract: Embodied agents hold great promise as educational assistants, \ exercise coaches, and team members in collaborative \ work. These roles will require agents to closely monitor the \ behavioral, emotional, and mental states of their users and \ provide appropriate, effective responses. Educational agents, \ for example, will have to monitor student attention and employ \ behavioral strategies when student engagement decreases. \ In this paper, we draw on techniques from brain-computer interfaces \ (BCI) and knowledge from educational psychology \ to design adaptive agents that monitor student attention in \ real time using measurements from electroencephalography \ (EEG) and recapture diminishing attention levels using verbal \ and nonverbal cues. We found that on average the adaptive \ agent which employed behavioral techniques to regain attention \ during drops in engagement improved student recall abilities \ 43% over the baseline and also significantly improved \ student motivation and rapport. Our findings offer guidelines \ for developing effective adaptive agents, particularly for educational \ settings.

Title: Semantic Interaction in Spatializations of Text Datasets
Author list: Alex Endert, Patrick Fiaux, Chris North
Keywords: Visualization
Abstract: Visual analytics emphasizes sensemaking through interactively exploring visualizations of large, complex datasets. Using statistical models, datasets are visualized and users are able to make sense of the data. For example, large textual datasets can be visualized in a spatial metaphor, where similarities between documents are represented through their relative spatial distances from other documents. By in large, users interact with such visualizations through visual controls, such as moving sliders, traversing menus, or entering values into text fields. Often, these interactions (or changes) correspond directly to parameters of the underlying statistical model of the visualization. However, once users are able to relate to the information within the visualization spatially, how can we design visualizations where they can also interact spatially? That is, how can we design visualizations with interactions that stay within the metaphor? In this paper, we present the opportunity for a new design space for visual analytic interaction, semantic interaction, where users can interact in the spatial metaphor created by the visualization. Further, we show how semantic interactions can be integrated into a visual analytic tool, ForceSPIRE, used for interactive analysis of textual data within a spatial visualization.

Title: Interpretation and Trust: Designing Model-Driven Visualizations for Text Analysis
Author list: Jason Chuang, Daniel Ramage, Christopher Manning, Jeffrey Heer
Keywords: Visualization; Database access / Information Retrieval; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design
Abstract: Statistical topic models can help analysts discover patterns in large text corpora by identifying recurring sets of words and enabling exploration by topical concepts. However, under- standing and validating the output of these models can itself be a challenging analysis task. In this paper, we offer two design considerations--interpretation and trust--for designing visualizations based on data-driven models. Interpretation refers to the facility with which an analyst makes inferences about the data through the lens of a model abstraction. Trust refers to the actual and perceived accuracy of an analyst's inferences. These considerations derive from our experiences developing the (Anonymized) Dissertation Browser, a tool for exploring over 9000 Ph.D. theses by topical similarity. We contribute a novel similarity measure for text collections based on a notion of "word-borrowing" and show how it arose from an iterative design process. Based on our experiences and a literature review, we distill a set of design recommendations and describe how they promote interpretable and trustworthy visual analysis tools.

Title: Improving Literacy in Developing Countries Using Speech Recognition-Supported Games on Mobile Devices
Author list: Anuj Kumar, Pooja Reddy, Anuj Tewari, Rajat Agrawal, Matthew Kam
Keywords: Speech I/O; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Children; Prototyping; Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Studies
Abstract: Learning to read in a second language is challenging, but highly rewarding. For low-income children in developing countries, this task can be significantly more challenging because of lack of access to high-quality schooling, but can potentially improve economic prospects at the same time. The research base suggests that having to practice recalling and vocalizing words for expressing an intended meaning could improve our word reading skill – including reading in a second language – far more than silent recognition of what the given words mean. Unfortunately, many language learning software do not support this instructional approach, owing to the technical challenges of incorporating speech recognition support to check that the learner is vocalizing the correct word. In this paper, we present results from a usability test and two subsequent experiments that explore the use of two speech recognition-enabled mobile games to help rural children in India read words with understanding. We discuss three major contributions of this work. First, through a working prototype, we demonstrate the technical feasibility of speech recognition that needs to account for diverse, low-resource contexts. Second, we give empirical evidence that shows the extent to which productive training (i.e. vocalizing words) that speech recognition supports is superior to receptive vocabulary training, and discuss the use of scaffolding hints to “unpack” factors in the learner’s linguistic knowledge that may impact reading. Third, we discuss what our results suggest for future research in HCI.

Title: Gesture Coder: A Tool for Programming Multi-Touch Gestures by Demonstration
Author list: Hao Lu, Yang Li
Keywords: Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; End-user Programming; Pen and Tactile Input
Abstract: Multi-touch gestures became popular on a wide range of touchscreen devices. However, programming multi-touch gestures remains an art. It is time-consuming and error-prone for a developer to handle the complicated touch state transitions resulted from the increasing number of fingers and their simultaneous movements. In this paper, we present Gesture Coder, a tool that automatically generates code for recognizing each state of multi-touch gestures and invoking corresponding application actions, based on a few gesture examples given by the developer. The generated code can be easily integrated into a project by developers. We evaluated Gesture Coder using a within-subject study in which participants were asked to implement a set of multi-touch interactions with and without Gesture Coder. The results overwhelmingly showed that Gesture Coder significantly lowered the threshold of programming multi-touch gestures.
